title: Keep your tomatoes fresh longer
author: Mary Hunt
content:
Keep your tomatoes fresh longer

 November 8, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mary Hunt | Page: 12 | Section: News 
 
 314
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A perfectly ripe, fresh, slightly crisp tomato elevates so many things, from salads to BLTs. But here's the problem: At my house, we frequently cannot consume them in the short window of a couple of days before they turn mushy and slightly spoiled.I have tested so many ways to keep tomatoes fresh long enough to use them - on the counter, upside down, in a closed container in the fridge, attached to the stem, to name a few.None were super satisfying.Another method that promised to give excellent results was to store a fresh tomato on the counter but turn it upside down so that it is resting on the stem area. At first, this seemed foolish to me, but I gave it a trial run anyway. Surprisingly, it did seem to help to extend freshness for a day or two, which at the time was exciting as it was better than other methods I tested. The idea is to shield the tomato's "opening" spot from heat and light.But this new method? It is now my absolute favorite and the only way I will ever store tomatoes.The theory is that cellophane tape applied securely to the tomato to cover the spot where the stem was attached to the vine, creates a barrier to hold moisture in and keep potential bacteria and mold out.Using this method, I can leave an unwashed, "taped" tomato on the counter for 10 days, and find it is as fresh as it was on day 1. I simply remove the tape, wash the tomato, slice and enjoy. That's it - the best way ever to store fresh tomatoes long enough to actually use them, without any detectable change in texture or flavor. Amazing.Mary invites you to visit her at EverydayCheapskate.com, where this column is archived complete with links and resources for all recommended products and services.Mary invites questions and comments at https://www.everydaycheapskate.com/contact/.CO PYR IGHT 2023 CREATORS.COM 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a practical agricultural technique for preserving tomatoes, a crop. While it touches on food storage (Health) and sustainability (Environment), the core subject aligns most directly with Agriculture as it relates to post-harvest handling of produce.

title: Highly pathogenic avian influenza confirmed in Caroline County - Transmission risk between birds and general public is low
author: Staff Report
content:
Highly pathogenic avian influenza confirmed in Caroline County - Transmission risk between birds and general public is low

 November 22, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Report | Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 407
 Words 

 Read News Document

 State laboratory testing detected a case of highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza (HPAI) in Caroline County, the Maryland Department of Agriculture announced Tuesday.Following increased mortality of a broiler operation and investigation by the Maryland Department of Agriculture, it has been preliminarily confirmed that poultry from the affected farm has tested positive for HPAI.This virus affects poultry, like chickens, ducks, and turkeys, along with some wild bird species such as ducks, geese, shorebirds and raptors.According to the Maryland Department of Health, the risk of transmission between birds and the general public is low.State officials have quarantined all affected premises, and birds on the properties are being or have been depopulated to prevent the spread of the disease. Birds from affected flocks will not enter the food system.Confirmation by the U.S. Department of Agriculture's National Veterinary Services Laboratory is pending, with final results anticipated in the coming days."High Pathogenic Avian influenza or HPAI does not affect poultry meat or egg products, which remain healthy and safe to eat and handle. Poultry growers, operators, and backyard flock owners should be on high alert of the threat of HPAI," said Maryland Department of Agriculture Secretary Kevin Atticks."The Maryland Department of Agriculture, local health department, USDA and partner organizations are working diligently to address the situation, including quarantining and testing nearby flocks." Avian influenza is a highly contagious airborne respiratory virus that spreads easily among birds through nasal and eye secretions, as well as manure. The virus can be spread in various ways from flock to flock, including by wild birds, through contact with infected poultry, by equipment, and on the clothing and shoes of caretakers.If HPAI is suspected on personal property, wild birds, or in a commercial operation, the Maryland Department of Agriculture recommends following common-sense biosecurity steps, including looking for signs of illness and knowing warning signs of infectious bird diseases.To report a possible case of HPAI, call the Maryland Department of Agriculture at 410-841-5810.Commercial chicken growers and backyard flock owners can email questions about the outbreak to MD.Birdflu@maryland.gov.Other key biosecurity practices include cleaning and disinfecting transportation, removing loose feed, keeping visitors to a minimum, washing hands before and after coming in contact with live poultry, providing disposable boot covers or disinfectant footbaths for anyone having contact with a flock, changing clothes before entering poultry areas and before exiting the property, cleaning and disinfecting tools and equipment before moving them to a new poultry facility. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a highly pathogenic avian influenza outbreak in poultry, detailing agricultural containment measures, biosecurity protocols, and the impact on poultry farming. title: A celebration of agriculture charity
author: Laura Tayman; ltayman@chespub.com
content:
A celebration of agriculture charity

 November 29, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Laura Tayman; ltayman@chespub.com | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 715
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE - When the board of Chesapeake Charities brainstormed about what they would like to focus on for their 2023 awards ceremony, they chose the most obvious choice for the Maryland Eastern Shore - agriculture.The organization held its eighth annual Celebration of Charity luncheon Nov. 16 at the Chesapeake Bay Beach Club in Stevensville. Three of the awardees are based on the Eastern Shore.The Maryland Grain Producers Utilization Board, headquartered in Queenstown, won the Volunteers of the Year award.Also awarded at the event were Agriculture Advocate of the Year Amy Cawley of Denton, who oversees Maryland Food Bank's Farm to Food Program; Philanthropist of the Year Jim Perdue of Purdue Farms based in Salisbury; and Nonprofit of the Year Wild Kid Acres in Edgewater.Maryland Secretary of Agriculture Kevin Atticks attended the event."Farming on the mind of an esteemed organization like this is a testament to just how important it is," he said."Agriculture and farming is the number one industry in Maryland." The Maryland Grain Producers Utilization Board administers the Maryland Grain Checkoff Program.Grain producers in Maryland voted to institute this voluntary checkoff program, which is funded by participating growers donating 0.5% of each Maryland bushel sold."The Maryland Grain Checkoff is refundable, and yet MGPUB has an average annual refund percentage of just 3.4%, demonstrating that Maryland farmers see the value in donating their hard-earned money to this important cause," Maryland Grain Producers Association Executive Director Lindsay Thompson stated in a press release.Notable education projects include providing primary funding for Maryland Public Television's Maryland Farm & Harvest, which has educated over 11 million viewers about Maryland agriculture. MGPUB also funds many youth agriculture education programs through Maryland Extension and FFA throughout the state.Amy Cawley, who oversees Maryland Food Bank's Farm to Food Bank Program, received the Agricultural Advocate award. Cawley, who grew up on a farm in Denton, said she knew for a long time that lots of fresh food was going to waste.Cawley grew the program from two participating farms in 2011 to 60 farms today."This is hundreds of thousands of pounds of food that people who were food-insecure wouldn't have received," she said. In 2023, Maryland farmers raised 1 million pounds of food in one single season through the program.A familiar name and face was honored this year as Philanthropist of the Year, Jim Perdue of Perdue Farms, headquartered in Salisbury."It's rare for a business to become bigger with each generation, but that's been the case with Perdue," Atticks said. "Though the business is food-based, it's also a people business." During the first week of November, the Purdue and McCormick companies delivered nutritious meals to 5,200 families on the Eastern Shore, and in fiscal year 2023, his foundation provided nearly $1.7 million to 71 nonprofits.This year's Nonprofit of the Year award went to Wild Kid Acres owned by Gerardo Martinez.A Naval Academy graduate and U.S. Marine, he dreamed of owning a farm while visiting El Salvador.He found just the spot, a 5-acre farm in Edgewater, where he took on the construction of the home and farm himself using "climate-smart agricultural practices." Martinez received requests to visit the farm and engage with the assortment of rescued animals who roam together freely on the property.In 2020, the family opened the farm for community agricultural enrichment.By 2021 Wild Kid Acres was thriving as a location for animal therapy clients, a summer enrichment camp and goat yoga.Martinez said he is also pleased to see minority communities come visit, sometimes seeing farms and animals for the first time.Audrey Scott, former chair and current member of the Chesapeake Charities board, suggested years ago holding the annual honor awards ceremony as a fundraiser. "I had been on another board, and they made a lot of money with these award dinners," she said. "Well, we're in the nonprofit business, so I said let's do our own." Chesapeake Charities is a community foundation, a tax-exempt public charity, for philanthropists to establish charitable funds or donate to a cause they support.With over 160 funds, the foundation works on charitable projects in nine counties: Anne Arundel, Calvert, Caroline, Charles, Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne's, St. Mary's and Talbot. 
 
 Caption: LAURA TAYMAN/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Jessica, Zaria and Gerardo Martinez accept the Nonprofit of the Year Award from Chesapeake Charities for Wild Kid Acres in Edgewater. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on an agriculture-focused charity event recognizing individuals and organizations in Maryland's agricultural sector. While there are secondary mentions of business practices and educational programs, the primary focus is on agriculture, farming, and related initiatives.

title: Cawley receives Ag Advocate Award
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
Cawley receives Ag Advocate Award

 November 29, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: 18 | Section: News 
 
 914
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE - Chesapeake Charities recognized Amy Cawley of Denton as Agriculture Advocate of the Year at its eighth annual Celebration of Charity luncheon Nov. 16 at the Chesapeake Bay Beach Club in Stevensville.Cawley has overseen the Maryland Food Bank's Farm to Food Program since June 2011 and was recently named its manager. The program "combines field gleanings, donations, and contract growing to form the cornerstone of the food bank's nutrition strategy," according to MFB's website."It's surreal to me to receive such a recognition - Agriculture Advocate of the Year just blows my mind," she said. "I said I was born an advocate because of Pop Pop and Dad and being in a farming family." The focus of this year's awards was agriculture.Three of this year's awardees are based on the Eastern Shore.The Maryland Grain Producers Utilization Board, headquartered in Queenstown, won the Volunteers of the Year award. MGPUB is a group of farmers helping farmers who have funded more than $26 million in grants to improve the profitability and sustainability of state agriculture and farm families. Philanthropist of the Year is Jim Perdue of Purdue Farms based in Salisbury.Nonprofit of the Year is Wild Kid Acres in Edgewater.Maryland Grain Producers Association Executive Director Lindsay Thompson nominated Cawley for the award."There's so many people that advocate for agriculture," Cawley said. "So, for Lindsay to nominate me and for it to be approved, I can't even put it into words." Cawley, who grew up on a farm in Denton, said she knew for a long time that lots of fresh food was going to waste.Calling her a "superhero," MFB states on its website that Cawley "has helped the program grow from its humble roots with just two partners - First Fruits Farms in northern Baltimore County and Arnold Farms in northeastern Queen Anne's County - into a powerhouse produce program with more than 60 farms that infuse our statewide food distribution efforts with hundreds of thousands of pounds of nutritious fruits and vegetables annually." Cawley said the program next year will be venturing into dairy and trying new kinds of vegetables and fruits to be mindful of foods other cultures eat."We get everything from apples to zucchini and everything in between, and now we're doing culturally inclusive crops that I had never heard of before," Cawley said. She said she's learning about Caribbean produce like callaloo, scotch bonnet peppers and Jamaican pumpkin. MFB is "trying to do a better job of" serving "all kinds of ethnicities and cultures." She recently earned her CDL license, enabling her to drive a tractor-trailer. A couple of weeks ago, Cawley "drove from Salisbury to Baltimore with 22 pallets of potatoes. Everything else was okay, but the (Chesapeake) Bay Bridge was very, very intimidating," she said."I've had upwards of 70 farms a year," Cawley said."My best year was 2014 as far as donations. We got 2 million pounds of produce donated from farmers off the Eastern Shore. Anywhere I can get produce in Maryland, I cover. I'm a onewoman show." "I'm always advocating for the farmers for the Maryland food bank because only 2% of the population farm, so none of my co-workers really understand agriculture," Cawley said. "I'm always educating them on produce and how Mother Nature influences that and how the contracts I set up may not come to fruition, or they may go over and above what we said because it was such a good year. I teach them on the seasonality, how it's packaged, how long it lasts." Not only does she advocate for farmers, Cawley said, "We're advocating for those who are food insecure all across Maryland, and that the need is out there, and how it can be anybody that's food insecure. It can be loss of a job, illness, accidents, anything. Most of us are one paycheck away from struggle, and we don't realize that until it happens." The farmers she works with are larger scale operations, backyard gardeners and even the Caroline-Dorchester County Fair, whose organizers donate "maybe 75 pounds of produce a year," she said."So (donations) can be 100 pounds to thousands of pounds. Every pound makes a difference." Cawley was accompanied to the awards luncheon by her mom Jane Cawley, who "was beaming from ear to ear," according to Charles Cawley, Amy's dad. Her pastor, the Rev. Mary Friel of St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Centreville, attended and offered a prayer at the luncheon.Friel received her invitation and called Cawley to congratulate her. "I asked her, 'What are you talking about?' I think they had told me a month before, but I forgot all about it," Cawley said."I thanked everybody that helped me get to where I am at the Maryland Food Bank," Cawley said in a Nov.25 interview. "I thanked my mom and dad. I thanked my Pop Pop. I thanked my friend Linda, who owns Clayton Farms (who) taught me everything I know about produce. I thanked LEAD Maryland. I thanked Hannah, my sister-in-law, because she went through LEAD Maryland. I thanked Butch who hired me, and I thanked the Food Bank for keeping me around." The LEAD Maryland Foundation manages and allocates funds directly to the education and training of emerging leaders serving agriculture, natural resources and rural communities.Laura Tayman contributed to this story. 
 
 Caption: COURTESY OF MARY LAND FOOD BANK
 
Amy Cawley poses with a bunch of collard greens donated to the Maryland Food Bank.
 
COURTESY OF CHESAPEAKE CHARITIES
 
Maryland Secretary of Agriculture Kevin Atticks congratulates Amy Cawley, director of the Maryland Food Bank's Farm to Food Bank program, who received this year's Chesapeake Charities Agriculture Advocate of the Year Award. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Amy Cawley's recognition as an Agriculture Advocate, detailing her work with the Maryland Food Bank's Farm to Food Program, agricultural sustainability, and advocacy for farmers. The central theme revolves around agricultural practices, food distribution, and rural community support, making 'Agriculture' the most precise category.

title: Evergreen Fresh - Cawley Tree Farm offers variety of fresh trees, greens
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
Evergreen Fresh - Cawley Tree Farm offers variety of fresh trees, greens

 November 29, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: 15 | Section: News 
 
 773
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - They've been farming west of Denton more than 100 years, and for over a quarter of that century, Cawley Family Farm has branched out to become the only Christmas tree farm in Caroline County.On the Saturday after Thanksgiving, a steady stream of families rolled up the lane of the farm, past the festively decorated John Deere combine, past the Cawley family home and past a huge pavilion housing cut evergreen trees from North Carolina."It's a beautiful day," said owner Charles Cawley." It's going good. We've got good trees. I got some beautiful trees - a little pricier than last year but still beautiful trees - got a lot on the lot, as you can see. The Canaans are going out of here like crazy." In addition to Canaan firs, Cawley grows Concolor and Douglas firs, blue spruce and white pine - all on about 15 acres of the farm."We can't grow Frasers, so we bring them in," Cawley said."But we're the only one that brings in a tree, recuts it and puts it in holding tanks. No one else does that. So we sell the freshest pre-cut trees you can buy." "They're very hard to get, but we've got some beautiful Frasers," he said.Cawley said it took him a while, but he "got to how to grow" Canaan firs about 15 years ago.He pampers them, irrigating, spoon-feeding and growing them in "real thick grass. It helps keep the roots cooler because it gets too hot here," he said.According to the National Christmas Tree Association, the Canaan fir is a "relative newcomer to the Christmas tree market, with many similarities to both Fraser and balsam firs." About 500 to 600 trees are brought in from North Carolina."We sold about 200 off the lot, so we're selling between 700 and 800 a year," Cawley said.Keeping the trees fresh is important to Cawley. "When we sell one of these (Frasers) they'll hold the needles as long as one of those out in the field," he said. "And these things drink a lot of water initially. I mean, we just got these the day before Thanksgiving, and I had to fill these tanks up a couple times, they soaked up that much water." Once the trees are rehydrated, they are shaken, drilled with a tapered bit, set up on a pin stand in a shallow steel basin and kept watered. The operation has two drilling machines, three shakers and plenty of water holding bins inside and outdoors.The 55-foot by 80-foot pavilion can be closed off when the wind whips up to keep the trees from dehydrating. "If we had to add a little heat, we can, but we haven't had to," he said.Cawley clearly takes pride in his product, and his family pitches in. Arriving at 7 a.m. was his 7-year-old grandson Bryant, ready to get started - and put in a 12-hour day.Cawley's eldest daughter, Amy, makes wreaths and wood-burned ornaments from slices of sawed off stumps. The focus is on customer service, so other family members, as well as employees, wait on customers, shake needles from trees, wrap net around them and tote them to cars.Cawley is vice president of the Maryland Christmas Tree Association. He said he started out as a farmer, "but I did a lot of things in the meantime," even working for "all three levels of government - county, state and federal. You don't build this by just farming. It takes something else," Cawley said, adding that his wife Jane is a retired school nurse.Several years of drought, along with root aphids in the Douglass firs and scale on some Canaans, have affected the growth and aesthetics of a few trees in the field, so Cawley has to be vigilant."There's a challenge every year," he said.Cawley Family Farm Christmas tree sales began Nov. 21.You can visit 10 a.m. to 7 p.m.Friday, Saturday and Sunday, and on Monday to Thursday by appointment. The farm is located at 24320 Willow Pond Road, Denton. For more information, call 410-479-4780 or 410-829-4781, or email info@cawley.farm. The website is www.cawleyfarms.com. 
 
 Caption: CONNIE CONNOLLY/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Charles Cawley of Cawley Family Farm takes pride in the freshness of his cut Fraser firs from North Carolina.
 
CONNIE CONNOLLY/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Bryant Cawley enjoys helping out as he carries cut evergreen branches to the wreath-making greenhouse.
 
CONNIE CONNOLLY/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Amy Cawley of Cawley Family Farm in Denton creates a variety of wood-burned Christmas ornaments from the trunks of cut evergreen trees.
 
CONNIE CONNOLLY/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Charles Cawley demonstrates how cut trees from North Carolina are rehydrated before they are ready to be sold.
 
CONNIE CONNOLLY/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Charles Cawley, right, his daughter Amy and his grandson Bryant all pitch in when it's Christmas tree selling season.

title: Fresh pork on the farm
author: Marie Savage; Country Cooking
content:
Fresh pork on the farm

 November 29, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Marie Savage; Country Cooking | Page: 20 | Section: News 
 
 1557
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Each year, my parents held two old-fashioned hog kills to fill the smokehouse and freezers with meat. once in November and once in March.This supply of meat fit perfectly with the previous summers canned vegetables, jellies, relishes, applesauce and much more. Did I mention the shed with potatoes, sweet potatoes, onions and turnips?It was not a lot of hard work because we all pitched in, and my dad had several farm hands helping.Everybody left at the end of the day with full stomachs and a package of sausage, scrapple or seasoning meat.Today, as I ride past the old farm place, I get upset looking thinking of those days gone by. I can still see the late Mr. Jim Showell ready to hang the meat and the late Mr. Ed Sturgis ready to hang the iron pots over the fire he would make.Mom would allow her children and grandchildren to ghelp h with the work, but she had a hand in all of it. especially the final taste testing of the sausage and scrapple.The morning of the slaughter found my sister and I scrubbing down the cutting surfaces, the mixing utensils, the pans to hold scrapple and the trays for both loose sausage and link sausage.In the smokehouse waited the exceptionally clean sharp meat hooks to hang the hams and shoulders. Finally, there were the cans to hold the fresh pressed lard. what a beautiful sight so pure clear white.The one job that my mother had every year was sausage maker.Either one of my brothers or nephews would feed the cut-up pork parts into the top of the grinder. My mother sat stretching sheep fs intestines for the casing over the tube and working the ground sausage as it fed into the intestines and into a large bowl.This was a job that I later inherited, and since it was the only job where you could actually sit at our hog killings, I didn ft mind.There are many funny stories associated with hog killing adventures throughout the years, but time will not allow today.In the next few winter months, I will slip them in. The one I love the most was when the could hogs have gotten me in big trouble, but my bus driver, the late Mr.George Hudson, was related to mom, and he was a farmer.One cold hog killing morning, I was leaving to go to school on the bus and I begged Mr. Sturgis to cut out the hog brains for my class to study in biology. He did, but he put them in a small brown paper bag.By the time we got to Stephen Decatur High School, the bag broke through as we got off the bus. My friend Nellie saw it first, screamed, hollered gdead h and everyone ran. I tried to explain to our new principal, but to no avail.He just didn ft understand a country girl fs ambition to succeed in biology.Enough of this. lets cook some delicious meals with pork.Ever heard of pork forshanks?The pork shank is the front forearm of the hog. This cut is tough because the pigs develop muscles living in the mud, which in turn gives the meat incredible flavor that tastes next-level compared to other parts of the hog fs body.The bone it surrounds has marrow that melts into a braise when slow cooked, making it extra rich.Which is perfect for this next recipe.BRAISED PORK SHANK1/2 cup all-purpose flour, 2 tbsps chili powder, 1 tbsp kosher salt (plus more to season), 1 tbsp freshly ground black pepper (plus more to season), 6 pork shanks (about 1 1/2 pounds each), 1/4 cup extra-virgin olive oil (divided), 1 medium onion (chopped), 2 medium carrots (chopped), 2 medium celery ribs (chopped), 6 garlic cloves (minced), 6 cups chicken stock or low-sodium broth, 3 rosemary sprigs, 2 bay leaves, 2 thyme sprigs. In a large, sturdy resealable plastic bag, combine the flour and chili powder with salt and pepper.Add the pork shanks, one at a time, and shake to coat thoroughly.In a large skillet, heat 2 tbsps of the olive oil until simmering.Add three of the pork shanks and cook over moderately high heat until browned all over, about 10 minutes. Transfer the browned shanks to a deep, heavy casserole. Wipe out the skillet and brown the remaining three pork shanks in the remaining 2 tbsps of olive oil; lower the heat if necessary. Add the pork shanks to the casserole. Add the onion, carrots, celery and garlic to the skillet and cook over moderate heat until softened, about 5 minutes. Add the wine and bring to a boil. Simmer until slightly reduced, about 2 minutes. Pour the vegetables over the pork. Add the stock, rosemary, bay leaves, and thyme; season with salt and pepper and bring to a boil. Tuck the pork shanks into the liquid so that they fre mostly submerged.Cover and cook over moderately low heat for 2 1/2 hours, or until the meat is very tender. Turn the pork shanks every 30 minutes to keep them submerged in the liquid.Transfer the braised shanks to a large, deep platter; cover and keep warm. Strain the liquid, pressing hard on the solids; discard the solids. Return the liquid to the casserole and boil until reduced to 4 cups, about 20 minutes.Spoon off the fat, pour the pork gravy over the braised shanks, and serve.COUNTRY PORK RIBS3 lb. country style pork ribs (about 8 ribs), 2 tsps smoked salt,. tsp black pepper, 2 tsps smoked paprika, 1 tsp dried thyme,. tsp cayenne pepper. Preheat your oven to 325 degrees. Arrange the ribs in a single layer in an ungreased 9x13-inch rimmed baking dish. Mix together the dry rub ingredients and sprinkle the rub on top of the ribs. Cover the baking dish tightly with heavy duty foil (or a double layer of regular foil), and bake until the ribs are very tender, about 2 hours.With a slotted spatula, remove the cooked ribs to a broiler-safe, foil-lined, rimmed baking sheet.Either flip them or place them on their side, so that the fat is exposed to the heating element.The goal is to brown it. Switch the oven to broil on high, and set an oven rack 6 inches below the heating element (not directly below). Baste the ribs with the pan juices, then broil them until the fat is browned, 3-4 minutes.Baste the ribs one more time with the pan juices and serve.PORK ROAST6-pound boneless Boston Butt (aka pork shoulder), 3 cloves garlic minced, 2 tsps salt, 2 tsps ground pepper, 1 tbsp chopped fresh sage, 1 tbsp chopped fresh rosemary, 2 large red onions (sliced into 1-inch thick wedges), olive oil, 1/2 cup reserved pan drippings. Preheat oven to 300 degrees. Tie roast well with kitchen twine and place it in a lightly oiled roasting pan.Rub roast with mix of herbs and garlic and place in roasting pan.Bake in preheated oven, uncovered, for 3 hours. Remove roast from pan and add onions; toss with pan drippings (if there isn ft enough fat in the pan, drizzle with a bit of olive oil and toss onions to coat). Place roast on top of onions and return to the oven, uncovered, for an additional 4 hours (check pan every hour to be sure the pan drippings don ft evaporate. add 2 cups of water if necessary).Remove the roast from the roasting pan and place it in a glass baking dish and allow it to cool before you wrap the dish well with plastic and put it in the fridge overnight.Reserve the onions and pan drippings separately in the fridge overnight too. You should have about 1 1/2 cups of drippings (maybe 1 1/4 after you remove the fat). Add water to the drippings if you don ft have enough.PORK LOIN CHOPS2 tbsp paprika, 1 tbsp salt,. tbsp ground black pepper,. tbsp garlic powder,. tbsp onion powder, 1 tsp dry mustard powder, 1 tsp ground sage,. tsp cayenne pepper (optional),. tsp celery salt (optional). Measure out all of the ingredients into a small mixing bowl. Set aside. Preheat your oven to 375 degrees and lightly grease or spray a baking dish with non-stick cooking spray. Wash and trim country-style pork loin chops as needed, then pat the pork dry using paper towels. Apply the pork seasoning to all sides of the pork chops generously. For about 2 lbs of country style pork loin chops, you fd use 2 tbsps of the pork seasoning. Place the seasoned country style pork loin chops into your prepared baking dish in a single layer. Bake in the middle of your oven fs center rack for 35-40 minutes, or until the pork reaches a minimum internal temperature of 145 degrees.Remove from the oven and serve immediately for best taste.PULLED PORK1 3lb. pork shoulder roast,. cup beef broth,. cup apple cider vinegar,. chopped yellow onion, 2 tbsps light brown sugar, 1 tbsp Worcestershire sauce, 1 tbsp yellow mustard, 1 bottle of your favorite BBQ sauce. Spread chopped onions on the bottom of the slow cooker. Add pork shoulder and pour in chicken broth, Worcestershire and cider vinegar right on the pork. Add mustard and brown sugar and use your hands to rub it all in the pork. Cover the slow cooker and set on high for 5 hours.Shred pork with 2 forks and pour in BBQ sauce. Don ft pour the whole bottle in. Just enough to cover the meat according to taste. Cover and cook on high for 1 more hour.Serve on your favorite sandwich rolls or buns. 
 
 Caption: METRO CREATIVE SERVICES
 
Marie Savage's pork chop recipe features nine different seasonings. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on traditional agricultural practices related to pork production, including hog killings, meat preservation, and recipes. While it includes elements of local life and food culture, the core subject is agriculture as it details farming methods and livestock management.

title: 'I'M Acting Like We'Re Running Out Of Time' - Agriculture Secretary Discusses Goals At Farm Bureau Annual Convention In Cambridge
author: Maggie Trovato; Mtrovato@Chespub. Com
content:
'I'M Acting Like We'Re Running Out Of Time' - Agriculture Secretary Discusses Goals At Farm Bureau Annual Convention In Cambridge

 December 6, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; Mtrovato@Chespub. Com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 736
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - In an address to the Maryland Farm Bureau, Maryland Secretary of Agriculture Kevin Atticks focused on the future of the industry.At the Farm Bureau's Annual Convention and Meeting of Delegates Monday afternoon in Cambridge, Atticks discussed the state's agriculture efforts and goals moving forward, along with some of the things it has already implemented."I'm acting like we're running out of time," he said during his speech."You're going to see us moving forward on things in a very proactive way."Toward the beginning of his address, Atticks named some of the pressures that Maryland's agriculture industry is facing, including development pressures and pressures related to the Chesapeake Bay. He said those pressures are informing everything the Department of Agriculture does.Regarding land, Atticks said many farms in the state are situated in the midst of a series of metropolitan areas."Those metro areas are combining and creating an unworldly amount of pressure for you to sell," he said. "Not crops, but land."To preserve these rural areas, Atticks said it is critical that these farms become more profitable."We're going to make it more profitable, which will in turn, preserve it," he said about the land.Atticks also talked about "doing well by the Bay and for the Bay." He said the state needs to reach and exceed its goals for the Chesapeake Bay.One of the department's efforts, he said, is focusing on blue catfish."In parts of the Bay, (blue catfish are) 80% of the biomass," he said.The blue catfish are eating crabs, rockfish and oysters - which is a problem for the health of the Bay."We're counting on oysters to help us clean the Bay," he said. "And this thing is eating the oysters."Atticks had everyone in the audience raise their right hands and repeat, "I promise to eat 250 pounds of catfish every week.""Come on, this is the interactive portion of the show," he said, drawing laughs from those in the audience.Throughout his speech, Atticks talked about value-added agriculture - using processing or packaging so that the product is not sold as an original raw product.He said this is something his department wants to make sure it is supporting so that farmers can increase their profits."We've added a state value-added specialist, which will help farmers across the state do some of the work that I've been doing in my prior career," he said. "Help folks get through the systems so that if they want to take their milk and actually sell milkshakes, they can do that."Atticks said this does not mean the state is turning its back on traditional agriculture."Traditional ag is critically important," he said. "But given the pressures that we're in and the margins that are being squeezed, traditional ag is going to require a lot more acreage."Atticks said the department is also working to make its nutrient management program better and modernize all of its programs and processes."We've got a very, very large Latino population who's attempting to get into the industry," he said. "And when all of our programs are in English only, that's not going to fly."Going to different counties and connecting with community members is another priority for Atticks."Because we need to keep having these conversations," he said. "All of the good or bad ideas that we're going to come up with over the next few years are going to be from talking with you."After Atticks spoke, Craig Beyrouty, the dean of the University of Maryland College of Agriculture and Natural Resources, spoke. He also discussed the future, focusing on the college's goals.He said that while enrollment has increased for graduate students, undergraduate enrollment has gone down."That's a nationwide trend," Beyrouty said. "If anything keeps us up at night, it's attracting more students into our program."Beyrouty said the College of Agriculture and Natural Resources has passionate staff and students."Our college was ranked, within the last five years, as having one of the top five undergraduate programs in agriculture in the nation in terms of return on investment," he said. "It's an outstanding program We just need to attract more students." 
 
 Caption: MAGGIE TROVATO/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Maryland Secretary of Agriculture Kevin Atticks discussed the future of Maryland's agriculture industry at the Maryland Farm Bureau Annual Convention and Meeting of Delegates Dec. 4 at the Hyatt Regency Chesapeake Bay Golf Resort, Spa And Marina in Cambridge. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Maryland's agriculture secretary discussing industry challenges, goals, and initiatives like land preservation, value-added agriculture, and Chesapeake Bay impacts. While environmental aspects are mentioned, the core subject is agriculture.

title: A celebration of agriculture charity - Foundation supports Eastern Shore ag communities
author: Laura Tayman; ltayman@chespub.com
content:
A celebration of agriculture charity - Foundation supports Eastern Shore ag communities

 December 12, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Laura Tayman; ltayman@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 745
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE - When the board of Chesapeake Charities brainstormed about what they would like to focus on for their 2023 awards ceremony, they chose the most obvious choice for the Maryland Eastern Shore - agriculture.Last week, the organization held its eighth annual awards ceremony with honorees that supported the Maryland agriculture community.Chesapeake Charities is a community foundation, a tax-exempt public charity, for philanthropists to establish charitable funds or donate to a cause they support.With over 160 funds, the foundation works on charitable projects in nine counties: Anne Arundel, Calvert, Caroline, Charles, Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne's, St. Mary's and Talbot.Working in partnership with donors and advisors, Chesapeake Charities has invested over $28 million in the areas of education, health and human services, community development, the arts, animal welfare, and the environment. This translates to thousands of grants for outstanding projects throughout the Chesapeake Bay region and beyond."We also do things like supply an awardee administrative costs, pay their bills, get tax exemption numbers," said Scott. "That way there is more money for them to support their cause." "Every new philanthropist knows that they have a support network allowing only a 4% overhead cost and our new stellar grant office has secured over $32 million," said Linda Kohler, Chesapeake Charities' executive director. "We are really good at multiplication," she said.Kevin Atticks, the Maryland Secretary of Agriculture, attended the event and told the audience that "agriculture and farming is the No. 1 industry in Maryland." Atticks said the Moore Administration has made support for rural areas in Maryland one of its top priorities."He's been to the Eastern Shore so many times, he's now starting to get calls from municipalities that say they need some attention, too," Atticks said."Farmers are accused of being commercial these days," Atticks said. "We need to give them tools to make them stronger and the tools to be profitable," said Atticks of his department's focus.A familiar name and face was honored this year as the Philanthropist of the Year, Jim Perdue of Perdue Farms."It's rare for a business to become bigger with each generation, but that's been the case with Perdue," said Atticks. "Though the business is food based, it's also a people business." Perdue is focused on all employees because he worked in every job of the company before taking the lead. He established wellness centers at each Perdue location with medical personnel for workers, all free. His was the first company to commit to no biotics protocol.Just last week the Purdue and the McCormick companies delivered nutritious meals to 5,200 families on the Eastern Shore, and in FY23, his foundation provided nearly $1.7 million to 71 nonprofits focusing efforts on education, agriculture, the environment, health and social services, public safety, and fighting hunger and poverty.When receiving the award, Perdue thanked his family and workers and told attendees, "I believe giving back is giving hope." Amy Cawley, Maryland Food Bank's Farm to Food Bank Program, received the Agricultural Advocate award.Cawley, who grew up on a farm in Denton in Caroline County, said she knew for a long time that lots of fresh food was going to waste.Cawley grew the program from two participating farms in 2011 to 60 farms participating today. "This is hundreds of thousands of pounds of food that people who were food-insecure wouldn't have received," she said. In 2023, Maryland farmers raised 1 million pounds of food in one single season through the program.This next year, Cawley said they are now venturing into dairy and are going to be trying new kinds of vegetables and fruits to grow to be mindful of foods other cultures eat.This year's Nonprofit of the Year award went to Wild Kid Acres owned by Gerardo Martinez.The Maryland Grain Producers Utilization Board, headquartered in Queenstown in Queen Anne's County, won the Charities' Volunteers of the Year award - a group of farmers helping farmers, who has funded more than $26 million in grants to improve the profitability and sustainability of state agriculture and farm families.One of their most notable projects was providing Maryland Public Television with a series about the lives of Maryland farmers. 
 
 Caption: COURTESY OF CHESAPEAKE CHARITIES
 
Maryland Secretary of Agriculture Kevin Atticks congratulates Amy Cawley, director of the Maryland Food Bank's Farm to Food Bank program, who received this year's Chesapeake Charities Advocate Award.
 
LAURA TAYMAN
 
Jessica, Zaria, and Gerardo Martinez accept the Nonprofit of the Year Award for their Wild Acre Farm in Edgewater, from Chesapeake Charities last week. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on agriculture through Chesapeake Charities' focus on supporting Maryland's agricultural communities, awards for agricultural advocates, and partnerships with farming organizations. While related topics like environment and education are mentioned, the core theme is explicitly agriculture.

title: Montaire starts a new era of grain storage on the Shore
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Montaire starts a new era of grain storage on the Shore

 January 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 475
 Words 

 Read News Document

 MILLSBORO, Del. — Mountaire Farms paid about $25 million for three grain elevators in a deal reach in December.The grain facilities — located in Preston, Cordova and Wye Mills — were purchased from Nagel Farm Services. According to the deed the multiple properties in Wye Mills and Preston were sold for $18.5 million. It includes six different properties. Another grain silo property in Cordova sold for $6.4 million, according to county special warranty deeds.
"Our intention is to operate these facilities with the same level of exceptional service that local farmers have come to expect from Nagel Farms," said Rex Holstein, vice president of agri-business for Mountaire Farms, at the time the deal was made. "At Mountaire, we are a family-owned company just like the Nagels, and we share similar values. We appreciate how they've managed their business through the years, and we can't wait to continue that legacy."
Mountaire will work with Nagel employees on transitioning their employment, benefits and seniority to Mountaire.
According to a Nagel-produced documentary, their culture is faith-based with a focus on doing the right thing by everyone they do business with.
Nagel Farm Service will retain their trucking, hardware and crop insurance businesses at the three Mid-Shore locations.
"They are still retaining some of their operations. We are just buying the grain storage facilities — the grain elevators. Crop insurance is not our expertise. That is not anything we would be interested in," said Bassett.
"Our agribusiness team buys and sells grain. We use the bulk of it to make chicken feed, certainly at our feed mills here on the shore. More storage capacity means the capacity to buy more local grain. That is important to our team. Sometimes there are other opportunities to buy and sell local grain. Our agri business team watches closely how grain is bought and sold," she said.
Mountaire currently owns nine grain elevators on Delmarva and three feed mills.
"The Nagel family and our team of trusted employees will continue to work together serving the farm community with the same level of care we have for nearly 80 years," said the Nagel family in a statement. "We are proud of the strong bond we have with our loyal customers and look forward to improving these relationships through unparalleled service. Mountaire, as an organization, is an excellent fit with Nagel Farm Service as we both operate from two critical principles: 1) prioritizing faith and 2) providing exceptional service to the farmer."
A Dec. 18 fire at the Wye Mills grain silo was put out quickly, and according to Catherine Bassett, director of communications at Mountaire, they were back to work the next day.
Those towering grain silos shimmered as the sun set and a new era began as the deal was inked. The $5 billion dollar poultry business on Delmarva keeps growing. These grain facilities are key locations for farmers on the Mid-Shore. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Mountaire Farms' acquisition of grain storage facilities, emphasizing agricultural operations, farmer relationships, and agribusiness practices. While there are business elements, the core subject is agriculture-related grain storage and farming infrastructure.

title: Caroline Zoning Appeals board denies Hartland Holdings grain silo variance
author: Connie Connolly
content:
Caroline Zoning Appeals board denies Hartland Holdings grain silo variance

 January 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly | Section: Local News 
 
 1365
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Over the course of two meetings and four hours of testimony and deliberation, the Caroline County Board of Zoning Appeals voted against granting a zoning variance to a agricultural operation near Greensboro.Benjamin Flahart of Quarryville, Pennsylvania, whose Hartland Holdings LLC owns the 160-acre farm in question, was denied a 43-foot variance for already-constructed grain silos at 14010 River Road.
His attorney, Brendan Mullaney of McAllister, DeTar, Showalter & Walker in Easton and Brett Ewing of Lane Engineering represented him at the Board's Nov. 19 meeting and attended the Dec. 19 meeting with Flahart. Both meetings were held at the Health and Public Services Building in Denton and were attended by about a dozen Caroline residents.
Board of Zoning Appeals Chair Karen Hardy, Vice Chair Ben Butler and Member Kevin Parks voted unanimously to deny the variance, claiming that Flahart knew, or should have known, that setting up grain bins within the county's 500-foot road setback requirement was a violation of the county code.
"It's the principle to me," Hardy said at the Nov. 14 meeting. "If … we just say, 'Okay, no problem, come on into Caroline County, put up what you want, and then whenever it doesn't go your way, just come on and bring your attorneys and … we'll give you your variance' — I don't want that to be something that happens here."
Several times during the course of both meetings, Hardy said Flahart had "created his own hardship."
Butler said he felt "the same way," although moving the grain bins would cost "a lot of money."
"But I really feel like he created this situation, and I just feel like he should have to move it," Butler said.
Flahart bought grain bins from Mountaire in Greensboro and moved them to the River Road location. Three of the bins are located within the setback limit. At the Dec. 19 meeting Flahart estimated demolishing and relocating the three bins would be "close to $1 million."
"I know that the financial hardship is severe, and I do understand that, but it is somewhat self-created," Hardy said after the unanimous vote. "I don't feel good about that decision. Unfortunately, we could not do it any other way."
The Board of Zoning Appeals considered two items related to Flahart's River Road operation. The first item considered at the Nov. 14 meeting involved a public hearing and an extended debate addressing Hartland Holdings LLC's application for a special use exception in accordance with the Caroline County Code.
Flahart's operation, permitted in 2019 to store his own grain, evolved into an "agricultural products processing plant" when it began storing grain from other farms and selling it, which required a special use exception.
Mullaney explained Hartland Holdings LLC "owns a significant amount of land" on the Eastern Shore — "1,000 acres in Cecil County, over 2,000 acres in Dorchester and over 1,500 acres in Caroline."
He added that "in Pennsylvania and many other counties, you don't have to permit things like grain silos and agricultural barns."
Despite the additional structures' being added to the grain operation without permission, Mullaney said he believed all the variance criteria were satisfied. He said he and Ewing had worked together to submit permit applications "to get all this stuff cleaned up with Planning and Codes, the building permitting department and the Office of Health."
According to Matt Kaczynski, assistant director of development review for Caroline County, in 2019 Flahart hired engineering company Red Barn Consulting, which, in turn reached out to the planning department for the requirements to establish an agricultural products processing facility.
Kaczynski said the timeline required by the county prompted the Red Barn engineer to scale back the operation "to basically one grain tank."
"It was our understanding … that (Flayhart) would come back later for an expansion," he said. "Fast forward to now … What was constructed and what is shown on the site plan now was not what was reviewed and approved as part of the building permit process, so we had received some complaints from neighbors in the area about what was going on onsite."
Kaczynski said Flahart may not have been aware of Red Barn's process, as Flahart maintained during the Dec. 19 meeting.
However, Hardy said on Nov. 14 Flahart should have been aware "to some degree what's happening. … At the end of the day, it just makes me question the integrity of the man who's moving into this."
She brought up briefly "the elephant in the room" that wasn't under consideration: Flahart's dissolved air flotation, or DAF, pit, which has been a source of controversy and was a concern addressed at the Dec. 12 Caroline County Commission meeting.
Several people spoke up during the public hearing.
Local farmer James Lewis, who is the extension agent for Caroline County, said he has hauled his grain to the River Road facility the last couple of years. He said the operation benefited the community and that he was concerned about the carbon footprint involved with tearing down and moving the bins 43 additional feet from the road.
Caroline County farmer John Saathoff said he was "mainly concerned about the precedent" that would be set, although he liked "the option of having another grain facility."
In 2019 Flahart didn't own 1,500 acres in the county, Saathoff said. "He owned one farm, and that one bin was able to accommodate that farm."
"Everybody knows initially his plan all along was to go commercial," but "it was going to take too long." Because Flahart had also erected a scale and scale house, "that was clear evidence, in my opinion, of his original intention."
"Those of us down here in the trenches (who) have been here all this time — we're bound by the law," Saathoff said. "Those of us who have been here for generations, every time we want to do something, we come in your office and we apply for a permit, and we do what we're supposed to do. And these people who hire their attorneys, they get to do whatever they want. I don't think that's how we want this county to be."
Brett Meyers, a farmer who lives next door to Flahart's River Road property, said the permitting process is "not negotiable."
"I find it hard to believe a man with enough wherewithal to buy all these farms (and) put these grain tanks up wouldn't have understood that there was a permitting process involved to build what he wanted to build and to have to adhere to a site plan," Meyers said.
Although the 43 feet was not "going to make too much of a difference," Meyers said, "I feel like you're going to open Pandora's box. Where does it stop with the grain and the tanks. How big is it going to get? … If you okay this, how far is it going to get?"
Mike and Suellen Woodward, whose property adjoins the operation, voiced several concerns, including the increased heavy truck traffic and the lack of communication to neighbors that would allow them to present concerns earlier about the operation's expansion.
"We've seen this happen from the beginning," Mike Woodward said. "I don't understand how he got all those grain bins up with no permit at all. I don't care about the grain operation. That doesn't bother me at all. But the part of the permitting process — something was skipped somewhere, whether he didn't follow through or somebody else didn't follow through."
"And that happens all the time," Kaczynski said. "More often than you would want to know. We issue building permits. We go out onsite to do final inspections, and we find that they've constructed various other things without permits."
The board considered the benefits to local farmers hauling their grain to a nearby facility, but noted Flahart's business expansion that ventured beyond the approved site plan.
After almost two hours of testimony and discussion Nov. 14 the board deliberated, voting unanimously to approve a special use exception with the conditions that the applicant receive final site plan approval from the planning director or commission prior to issuing a permit and/or zoning certificate.
A further condition required the applicant and county entering into a development rights and responsibilities agreement to work with the Department of Public Works to address wear and tear on county roads affected by Hartland Holdings LLC's truck traffic. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on an agricultural operation's zoning variance dispute, detailing regulatory challenges faced by a farm storing grain. While local government procedures are involved, the core subject is the agricultural business's compliance with zoning laws, making 'Agriculture' the most specific and accurate category.

title: Queen Anne's County fairgrounds undergoing facelift
author: DOUG BISHOP dbishop@chespub.com
content:
Queen Anne's County fairgrounds undergoing facelift

 January 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DOUG BISHOP dbishop@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 366
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Since October, demolition of old barns at the 4-H Park in Centreville and immediate new construction of barns to replace them have been underway.Construction was made possible by funds directed by the Queen Anne's County Economic Development & Tourism Office with grant funding from the Rural Maryland Economic Development Fund provided by Upper Shore Regional Council and the Maryland Department of Commerce.
The 4-H Park capital improvements were provided $1.2 million. They include not only replacing the old barns, which have stood for more than 80 years, but improvements to electricity, plumbing and stormwater management on the fairgrounds.
For as long as anyone can remember, stormwater has flooded the fairgrounds many times, with excess water standing on the grounds for days after heavy rain storms.
Incremental work had been done on storm management over the years, with some improvements, however, this storm water management project will make substantial improvements in that area going forward.
"Before leaving office, Governor Larry Hogan provided funds for rural counties that had been impacted by the COVID pandemic," said Economic and Tourism Development Director Heather Tinelli. "All the rural counties in Maryland received funds for projects to help strengthen our agricultural communities in our state. Governor Hogan provided $50 million total for all the rural counties. QA received $2.9 million for 11 different projects. The improvements at the 4-H Park is the largest project of them all in our county."
"Our 4-H Park reflects the importance of our agricultural community, as well as how popular our annual county fair is to us," she added.
It's been noted that the Queen Anne's County Fair is by far the largest social gathering of people in the county each year. No other event comes close, with an annual paid attendance of 25,000 people over six days.
Those numbers were true before the pandemic began, and the fair numbers have returned since the pandemic ended.
Park Board member Berl Jastram is the Buildings and Grounds chairman. He has worked closely with Tinelli with the 4-H Park receiving the grant funds for the improvements and overseeing the work that has been done thus far.
It is expected improvements will be completed sometime this spring, long before the county fair arrives in August. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on infrastructure improvements at a 4-H Park, which is directly tied to agricultural communities. While economic development funding is mentioned, the core subject is the agricultural fairgrounds and their role in county agricultural events.

title: Cardin visits Teddy Bear Fresh during Eastern Shore tour
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Cardin visits Teddy Bear Fresh during Eastern Shore tour

 February 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 556
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — U.S. Sen. Ben Cardin came to visit the Eastern Shore to discuss agriculture and aquaculture on Monday. His first stop was on Glebe Road to tour the Teddy Bear Fresh Produce facility.The group took a chilly 39-degree tour of Teddy Bear Fresh. The refrigeration was loud as they passed boxes of strawberries and kosher dill spears.
Mary Salins, the owner of Teddy Bear Fresh, a produce and foodservice item provider, has been looking for a way to expand her family business for seven years, she said.
The facility helps the year-round agricultural cycle by providing a market with vast refrigerated storage. Farmers don't need to get stuck with produce they can't sell, and Salins can sell wholesale to school systems, health care facilities, restaurants and others, with her trucks moving the vegetables to locations farther away.
This supports the cycles that farms naturally work in but provides a longer shelf life for their produce, Salins said.
Cardin said, "You are providing stability to farmers. You are giving them a market. We are so supportive of local sourcing and making that a reality."
Salins wrote in an email, "The non profit ESEC (Eastern Shore Entrepreneurship Center) received that money. Mike Thielke stated that he was with ESEC when he talked about those funds. Teddy Bear Fresh has not received any state funds. We are hoping to collaborate with ESEC in the near future."
Thielke is the Executive Director of ESEC.
Mike Thielke further clarified in an email, "Yes it was a grant to ESEC. It was submitted for funding by both Sen. Ben Cardin and Sen. Van Hollen. ESEC applied for a USDA grant in support of creating a regional produce processing and aggregation facility."
He went on to write, "ESEC and Teddy Bear Fresh have agreed to work together on creating the processing/aggregating facility. ESEC alone could bring about the facility. ESEC is bringing to the table the grant funds it has received and combining it with TBF's expertise and resources."
$985,000 is the size of the grant.
"It is going to be larger than this building," Salins said. "We will have a processing center as well as a larger freezer. We distribute out in wholesale, because of where we are, we have a lot of farms to pick up from."
At Teddy Bear Fresh, Cardin joined Letitia Nichols, deputy state director of USDA Rural Development for Maryland and Delaware; Scott Warner, executive director of the Mid Shore Regional Council; and local leaders.
Easton Mayor Megan Cook, Director of Economic Development and Tourism in Talbot Cassandra Van Hooser and Mike Detmer, representing Rep. Andy Harris' office, were also in attendance.
Following the tour of Teddy Bear Fresh, Cardin traveled to Chesapeake College to host a roundtable discussion with representatives from the Shore's agriculture, aquaculture and environmental conservation communities.
Following the discussion, Cardin joined individuals featured in the Maryland Public Television documentary, "Water's Edge: Black Watermen of the Chesapeake" to hear from them and better understand the plight of Black watermen, their history on the Shore and what, if any role, the U.S. government can play to help.
For the final event of the day, Cardin visited TechOps Specialty Vehicles, a business that specializes in the design and production of a wide variety of mobile vehicle-based solutions, for a tour of the facility. TechOps is headquartered in Stevensville and has several federal vehicle contracts.
This has been an updated version. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Senator Ben Cardin's visit to discuss agriculture and aquaculture, highlighting Teddy Bear Fresh's role in supporting farmers through storage and distribution. Key elements include USDA grants, agricultural partnerships, and infrastructure expansion, all central to the Agriculture topic. While Business/Economy and Environment are tangentially relevant, the primary focus remains on agricultural practices and support systems.

title: MPT's Maryland Farm and Harvest tours Dorchester County farm
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
MPT's Maryland Farm and Harvest tours Dorchester County farm

 February 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 405
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — The upcoming episode of Maryland Public Television's Maryland Farm and Harvest will hit home for Dorchester County residents.A segment of this season's 10th episode of the series, airing Tuesday, Feb. 13, at 7 p.m., will delve into the topic of saltwater intrusion with Cambridge-based grain farmer Wendell Meekins.
Meekins, a grain and poultry farmer who was born and raised in Dorchester County, has been in the business for 27 years.
According to a news release from MPT, Meekins will give a survey of his fields in the episode to show how how high soil salinity has affected his crops.
In the segment, University of Maryland Agroecology Lab Director Kate Tulley discusses the issue and possible solutions, including flood lands, natural buffers and repurposing land.
Last year, a tidal event killed about 65 acres of corn that Meekins had planted. In an interview, Meekins said the loss of income that farmers are facing due to this problem are "very great."
Although some people say saltwater intrusion is due to sinking ground, Meekins largely attributes it to erosion.
"We're seeing hundreds of acres in 10 years time that are eroding away," he said. "And that's causing sediment to decrease the depth of the rivers and creeks and tributaries."
As a result, he said, areas that don't normally flood are becoming flooded.
Meekins said subsurface saltwater intrusion, where saltwater is getting into ground water, is also an issue.
Robert Ferrier, series producer for Maryland Farm and Harvest, said low-lying counties are especially susceptible to these problems with saltwater.
"While it only affects a small portion of our state, it's something that I think everyone needs to be aware of," he said.
Ferrier said this issue has become more prevalent with sea level rise and increasing tide levels.
"It's something that we have to pay attention to," he said.
And this problem is not one that solely affects the farming community.
"Anybody that lives near a waterway has trouble with tidal flows," Meekins said. "Homes are getting flooded out. It's just becoming an increasing problem — for not only the farmer, but for the homeowner."
This segment is one of three in the episode. The episode also shows how a Harford County family is working to grow and sustain its farm and gets into locally produced wines at a vineyard in Frederick County.
Maryland Farm and Harvest, which is in its 11th season, tells a variety of stories about agriculture in Maryland.
The episode will also be available on mpt.org/farm on Feb. 13. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on agricultural challenges faced by Dorchester County farmers due to saltwater intrusion, featuring a farmer's experience and environmental impacts on farming. While environmental factors are discussed, the primary context is agriculture.

title: What's for dinner?
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
What's for dinner?

 February 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1390
 Words 

 Read News Document

 That familiar question pops up this time of the year as we are all in the same predicament — what is for dinner tonight?The cook needs new suggestions, and the diners don't care as long as it is not the same old dishes. Well friends, let me try to make you all happy and even give you a laugh or two.
Let's travel back down to farm country and visit the good ol' boys on a wintry Saturday morning. They just ate a breakfast consisting of fresh fried eggs, fried potatoes, mama's fresh baked biscuits and a couple slices of scrapple from the last hog killing.
The boys are ready to trap, catch, chase and hunt new meat. The brothers are used to these adventures and the boys from town love the fun.
As they speed off, Mom and I start our Saturday morning chores and wonder what these boys will bring home today?
Screeching tires, barking dogs and loud music tell us the "boys are back." It is about 1 p.m., and they start unloading the "supply." First we see muskrats, then rabbits, then a deer and then ... the biggest bull frogs ever. At this point I am leaving for my babysitting job in town.
Next week, we'll go even further into our trapping days for some good "wild game recipes." Well, hop right on in the kitchen and try something different for dinner tonight.
FROG LEGS
12 frog's legs, 2 eggs, 1 small jug lemon juice, 2 parsley sprigs, chopped dried bread crumbs, salt and pepper (to taste), oil. Preheat the oven at 375 degrees. Remove skin from frog legs. Wash and drain. Add lemon juice, salt and pepper to frog legs. Beat eggs in a separate bowl. Add chopped parsley. Soak frog legs in the eggs. Roll frog legs in breadcrumbs. Add enough oil to a large pan to allow for frying. Fry frog legs in the oven for 3 to 4 minutes.
SLOW BRAISED OX TAILS
4-5 oxtails, 4 large carrots (peeled and finely chopped), 1 onion (finely chopped), 2 stalks celery (finely chopped), 5 garlic cloves (finely chopped), 3 bay leaves, 2 sprigs rosemary, 14oz chopped tomatoes, 4 cups beef stock, salt and pepper to taste. Season the oxtail generously with salt. In a large pot set over high heat, brown the oxtail in batches. Remove and set aside. Add the onions, celery and carrots and cook until golden and just starting to soften. Add the garlic and herbs and sauté for another minute. Add the tomatoes and the oxtail back to the pot. Pour in the stock, just enough to cover the oxtail. Reserve the rest. Season with salt and pepper. Bring to a boil then reduce the heat, cover and simmer gently for 3 hours. Check every 45 minutes if the oxtail needs more stock and top up as needed. Remove the lid for the last hour of cooking to allow the sauce to reduce. Serve the soft oxtail with mashed potatoes, polenta or rice.
RABBIT STEW
3 to 4 lbs rabbit, 6 potatoes (quartered), 8 carrots (sliced), 1 medium onion (chopped), 1 tsp salt, 1/4 cup beef consommé, 3/4 cup beef broth, 3/4 tsp pepper, 1/4 tsp basil, 2 bay leaves, 1/4 tsp rosemary, 1/4 tsp thyme. Cut rabbit into pieces. Layer onion, potatoes, and carrots in the bottom of a crock pot. Add spices to the pot. Add rabbit, salt, pepper, consommé, and about 3/4 cup beef broth. Cover and cook on low for 8 hours. Thicken gravy as desired and serve hot.
BISON SLOPPY JOES
1 tbsp extra-virgin olive oil, 1 medium yellow onion (chopped, 1 red bell pepper (seeds and ribs removed, chopped), 1/2 cup ketchup, 2 cloves garlic (finely chopped), 1 tbsp chili powder, 2 tbsps apple cider vinegar, 2 tbsps yellow mustard, 1 tbsp brown sugar, 1 tbsp Worcestershire sauce, Kosher salt, freshly ground black pepper, 1 lb. ground Bison beef, 1 cup canned tomato sauce, 6 hamburger buns. In a large skillet over medium-high heat, heat oil. Cook onion and bell pepper, stirring occasionally, until softened and slightly golden, 10 to 15 minutes. Add ketchup and cook, stirring occasionally, until color has darkened and ketchup is reduced to a thick paste, 7 to 10 minutes. Add garlic and chili powder and cook, stirring, until fragrant, about 1 minute. Add vinegar, mustard, brown sugar and Worcestershire sauce; season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring frequently, until incorporated, about 1 minute more. Increase heat to high and add ground beef. Using a fork, break apart beef until separated and no big lumps remain. Cook, stirring frequently, until browned, about 5 minutes. Add tomato sauce and bring to a boil, stirring to combine. Let cool slightly; season with salt, if needed. Spread on buns or eat by itself.
PIGS FEET
4 lbs pig's feet, 1 tbsp cooking oil, 1 onion (coarsely chopped), 1 tbsp garlic (minced), 1 tsp thyme, ½ cup green bell pepper (coarsely chopped), ½ cup red bell pepper (coarsely chopped), ½ cup celery (coarsely chopped), 2 bay leaves, 1 tbsp bouillon powder, 1 tsp paprika, ½ cup white wine vinegar, 4-5 cups water, salt and pepper to taste, ½ tsp red pepper flake. Wash pig's feet in salt water, then scrub and rinse properly to ensure they are extra clean. Place a medium-size pot over medium heat. Add in cooking oil, onion, garlic and thyme. Saute for about 2-3 minutes. Then add bell peppers and celery and saute for another minute. Next, add pig's feet, bay leaves, bouillon, paprika, white wine vinegar and about 3 cups of water. Give everything a nice stir, then season with salt and pepper to taste. Cover pot and place pot over medium-high heat. Cook for about 2-3 hours, stirring periodically until the pig's feet are tender. Keep matching the pot to make sure water has not boiled out. If it has, add more.
CRISPY ALLIGATOR BITES
1 lb alligator meat tail or filet, 1 cup buttermilk, 1 tbsp Louisiana hot sauce, 1 cup flour, 1 tbsp Cajun seasoning, vegetable oil for frying. Cut the alligator into 1-2 inch pieces. Combine the buttermilk with the hot sauce, then add the alligator. Let it soak for 2-4 hours in the fridge. Mix the Cajun seasoning and flour together. Heat oil in a Dutch oven or other deep pot to 350 degrees. Oil should be about 3 inches deep. Dip the alligator pieces in the flour mixture then gently place them in the oil. Cook for 5-8 minutes, until golden brown on the outside. Cook in 3 batches to ensure each batch fries up crisp and non-greasy. Remove and drain on paper towels. Serve with Cajun remoulade sauce or dip in ranch dressing.
BAKED OPOSSUM
1 large opossum (skinned, dressed and washed), 4 tbsps Tabasco sauce, 1 1/2 tbsps salt, 2 onions (chopped), 1 clove garlic (minced), 2 tbsps Worcestershire sauce, 4 sweet potatoes, 2 ribs celery (chopped). Mix the salt, Tabasco sauce and Worcestershire sauce together. Place opossum in a large roasting pan. Sprinkle the celery, onions, and the garlic all over the opossum. Pour the liquid mixture over the opossum as well. Cover and refrigerate overnight. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Place the sweet potatoes around the opossum. Bake covered for 1 1/2 hours. Baste once or twice with the marinade from the pan as the opossum cooks.
Here are a few odd and fun ones to try with the kids when you have that restless Saturday or Sunday afternoon.
FRITO PIE
1cup corn chips, 1 cup prepared chili, 1/4 cup shredded cheddar cheese, 2 tsps chopped onions and mustard. Assemble by heating chili until warm either in a pot on the stove or in a microwave. Place corn chips in a bowl, pour over chili then top with the cheese, and onions if desired. Finish with a squirt of mustard.
KOOL AID PICKLES
1 (46 ounce) jar whole dill pickles, 1 cup sugar, 2 cups water, 2 (1 ounce) packets kool-aid unsweetened cherry drink mix. Drain and discard the juice from the pickle jar. Remove the pickles from the jar and cut each one in half lengthwise. Return the pickles to the jar and set aside. In a large measuring cup, combine the sugar, water and Kool-Aid. Mix until the sugar has completely dissolved. Pour enough of the liquid into the pickle jar to cover the pickles. Discard any excess. Cover the jar and refrigerate it for at least 24 hours.
