title: Talbot Planning Commission plans to draft memorandum for new farms
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Talbot Planning Commission plans to draft memorandum for new farms

 March 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 519
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Wednesday morning, the Talbot County Planning Commission met to approve local requests and discuss the potential of refining the language for farm-based recreational use properties.The Planning Commission voted to approve the major site plan for Brad and Lisa Bebbe's farm-based recreation use. The Bebbes plan to rent out their farm as a venue for weddings and other events. This was the second time Bebbe representatives met with the Planning Commission.
The first time, they were told to "do more," which Zack Smith, a representative for the Bebbes, described as vague.
"We felt at that time and still feel today we demonstrated compliance with technical requirements of the code for that use," Smith said. "... If you feel like what's in the code today isn't consistent with what that intent was, then maybe, like you discussed last month, (this may be) reason to revisit it and perhaps make some modifications."
The commissioners expressed uneasiness with having a farm's primary function be solely an event venue. The commission wanted the owners to view the farm less as a venue and lean more into agriculture.
Smith shared the Bebbes' plan to add bee colonies to the property.
Smith said that Lisa Ghezzi, a master beekeeper from the Maryland State Beekeepers Association, would establish two bee colonies on the property and invite members of the public to learn about beekeeping and raise awareness of bees' role in pollination agriculture. Smith added that there would be potential to market honey, beeswax and other beekeeping products from the colonies.
The commission voted to approve the application; they saw the beekeeping and education component as positively supplementing the farm-based recreation application.
The commission concluded that this application brought up an essential topic regarding language and intent to the commission. Commissioner Paul Spies expressed concern about setting a precedent by allowing recreational-use farms under the current language of the ongoing code and not focusing on agriculture farms.
The other commissioners agreed that the code should prioritize agriculture as the primary use and profit driver rather than supplemental activities like weddings.
The Planning Commission plans to draft a memorandum summarizing the discussion at the Wednesday morning meeting about refining the language for farm-based recreational uses in the zoning code. The commissioners will forward the memorandum to the County Council for consideration, with recommendations to strengthen language ensuring supplemental uses are genuinely ancillary to the primary agricultural use.
The commissioners said they want to help support working farms and young farmers in the agricultural industry, which can be financially challenging. Spies felt concerned that setting a precedent where the supplemental uses could become the main primary income rather than agricultural could lead to more properties being used primarily for non-agricultural events rather than actual farming over time.
Spies said allowing supplemental income was meant to help farming families, not replace farming as the leading enterprise for these businesses.
"It's hard to be a young farmer, it's hard to start out in the industry, it's hard to maintain organic, but if we gave them (farmers) an opportunity to supplement that income with something, then I could see more opportunities in the industry that I love and support," Spies said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on agricultural land use, zoning code discussions, and the Planning Commission's role in regulating farm-based recreational activities. While local government processes are involved, the core subject is agriculture policy and its implications for farming practices.

title: Queenstown Bank hosts Farmer's Luncheon
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Queenstown Bank hosts Farmer's Luncheon

 March 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 552
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EAST NEW MARKET — A group of Eastern Shore farmers gathered Friday afternoon at the East New Market Fire House to hear Dick Willey, former president of Perdue AgriBusiness, give his insights into the upcoming season.The event was hosted by Queenstown Bank and lunch was catered by Old Salty's Restaurant.
Queenstown Bank's Tracy Whitby-Fairall said that the event was not a sales event.
"This is an event for the farming industry and the community," she said.
After the presentation, Whitby-Fairall let the attendees know that, if wanted, Queenstown employees were present and able to talk about loan needs or answer any questions.
Willey's presentation delved into the corn and soybean markets.
He estimated the trading range for corn this year will be between $4 and $5.65 per bushel.
"That's not what you want to hear," he said. "But when I look at the technicals, and when I look at what I've seen from a historical standpoint, that's where I would venture to estimate."
For soybeans, Willey estimated the trading range this year will be $11.50 to $15.50 per bushel.
He estimated the cost of production per bushel will be $4.78 for corn and $11.80 for soybeans this year. In other words, margins could be small if the prices stay at the low end of the estimate.
Willey's presentation touched on wheat and weather. He said he didn't have any positive insights on wheat supply and use.
"So many Mid-Atlantic mills have closed," he said. "What's been going on across the country is it's just not a pleasant deal."
Willey said that in 2001, the United States had a total of 63 million acres of wheat. The estimate for 2024 and 2025 is 16 million less acres.
Touching on climate change, Willey said extreme weather is becoming the norm.
"Don't be a climate denier," he said. "There are a lot of people that are still denying that we have a climate problem. It's real."
Michael Bostic Jr., a farmer in Church Hill, said he was not surprised by Willey's insights.
"It's our job to keep up on stuff like this," he said. "It's all been in the pipeline for a while."
Bostic, who grows corn, wheat and soybeans, said he is trying to stay optimistic about what's to come this year.
"But it's not going to be great," he said.
At the end of his presentation, Willey encouraged the farmers in the audience to consider their supply chain in relation to value chain, or how much money is in a product.
"When somebody buys it, how much money does that generate and what percentage of it do you get?" he said, explaining what value chain is.
Willey encouraged the audience to consider artificial intelligence's place in all this.
"You guys are really good at knowing what your costs are," he said. "With AI, I think we're going to find a way to not only know what the costs are, but we're going to find out, not only the supply chain, but what the value chain is. And remember, other people will be able to figure out what your portion of the value chain is."
Willey said he thinks that in the next four or five years, there will be a trend in people deciding they want to raise prices on the things that go into producing a crop.
"Because there's so much money in the value chain, and they want more of it," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on agricultural market insights for farmers, including corn, soybean, and wheat price projections, production costs, and supply chain discussions. While there are economic elements, the core subject is agriculture-related.

title: Van Hollen hears from Eastern Shore farmers on Farm Bill
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Van Hollen hears from Eastern Shore farmers on Farm Bill

 March 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 642
 Words 

 Read News Document

 QUEENSTOWN — On a trip to the Eastern Shore Friday, U.S. Sen. Chris Van Hollen (D-Md.) heard from local farmers and members of agricultural organizations on what is most important to them when it comes to the Farm Bill.The Farm Bill is a package of legislation that includes various agriculture and nutrition programs, from crop insurance to the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, or SNAP. The federal bill needs to be reauthorized. In November, the bill was extended to allow programs to continue through Sept. 30.
The roundtable at Wye Research and Education Center was the final stop on Van Hollen's tour Friday. He also visited Tilghman Island Seafood with Sen. Ben Cardin (D-Md.) for a blue catfish processing tour, went to For All Seasons in Easton to learn more about mental health, education and rape crisis services provided in the Mid-Shore and visited J.M. Clayton Seafood Company in Cambridge to tour and talk with seafood processors about the H-2B visa program.
Maryland Secretary of Agriculture Kevin Atticks joined for the roundtable discussion with farmers Friday afternoon in Queenstown.
Van Hollen said the purpose of the roundtable was to hear to everyone else in the room. In an interview after the roundtable, he said these listening sessions help inform decisions made on Capitol Hill.
The roundtable was made up of Eastern Shore farmers and members of organizations such as the Maryland Farm Bureau and Horizon Farm Credit.
"They're in the best position to know what changes we need to make to update the Farm Bill," Van Hollen said in the interview. "We reauthorize the Farm Bill from time to time, and the whole reason we go through that process is because things change. And so, it's our opportunity to update programs, to add new things, to get rid of things that are no longer necessary."
During the discussion, members of the roundtable went around the room, sharing their interests and concerns when it comes to the Farm Bill.
Andy Mason, a dairy farmer in Kent County, spoke about the importance of the Environmental Quality Incentives Program and risk management programs.
"My other thing would be to get it done," he said. "That's obviously a political issue at this point, but our livelihoods and businesses are very much impacted by the Farm Bill."
Jennie Schmidt of Schmidt Farms in Queen Anne's County said that when it comes to crop insurance, better coverage is needed for vegetable and specialty crops. She said that when it comes to vegetables, the Farm Bill crop insurance program has good coverage for processing vegetables, but not for fresh market vegetables.
Jonathan Quinn, a Kent County grain farmer and vice president of the Maryland Farm Bureau, called crop insurance a key part of farm operations.
"It doesn't pay all the bills, but it keeps us going," he said. "So that is one of the things that need to be at the forefront."
Lindsay Thompson, owner of Thompson Ag Consulting, brought up technical assistance programming. She asked for language in the bill that will make it so that certified crop advisors automatically become technical service providers. She said this language was included in the 2018 Farm Bill but was never implemented.
Marshal Cahall, a grain farmer in Kent and Queen Anne's counties and District 5 director of the Maryland Farm Bureau, said the Farm Bill should be thought of as a food security bill. He said it's important to think about the connection between SNAP benefits and the farm programs that contribute to a secure supply of food for the American consumer.
Toward the end of the roundtable, Atticks spoke about coordination and collaboration, saying that a lot of money is going into food security programs and a lot of money is going into supporting local farmers.
"If the folks we were giving the money to to support the food programs had to buy local," he said, "we wouldn't have to support farmers as much." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on U.S. Sen. Chris Van Hollen meeting with Eastern Shore farmers to discuss the Farm Bill, which is a core agricultural policy document. The content centers on agricultural programs, crop insurance, and farmer concerns, directly aligning with the 'Agriculture' topic. While there is a local aspect, the primary subject is agricultural policy rather than local governance or economic factors.

title: Cage-free egg bill cracks under pressure
author: KIERSTEN HACKER Capital News Service
content:
Cage-free egg bill cracks under pressure

 March 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KIERSTEN HACKER Capital News Service | Section: General Assembly 
 
 760
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — A bill promoting cage-free eggs once got people excited but now it's stuck in committee, leaving sponsors uncertain if its future is on the sunny side.The measure would require all shell eggs raised or sold in Maryland to be cage-free by 2026. This would prohibit Maryland farmers with over 3,000 egg-laying hens from using what's known as battery cages, or conventional wire cages where hens are kept in close confinement.
The law would also require any eggs sold in Maryland supplied by other states to be cage-free.
"I think that we should be treating animals humanely," said House lead sponsor Del. Jennifer Terrasa (D-Howard County). "I think that's the bottom line."
But despite early optimism, Sen. Karen Lewis Young (D-Frederick), the Senate sponsor, tells Capital News Service she doesn't expect the bill to advance this session, even though she thinks cage-free eggs are "inevitable."
A stalemate would be at least a short-term win for agricultural interests in their ongoing national fight with animal rights advocates. The Humane Society has been advocating for cage-free eggs across the country, recently launching a six-figure advertising campaign for this legislation in Maryland. Some farms have adopted cage-free practices voluntarily.
Many farmers are against putting the requirement in law because of the increased cost of production, short phase-in period and potential for their birds to experience heightened health risks outside of the cage.
Farmers want to make their own decisions for how to best raise their birds.
Some advocates are surprised the legislation hasn't been successful in Maryland as other states passed similar laws regarding cages for farm animals. It's "rare" for Maryland to be behind on humane legislation, said Jennifer Bevan-Dangel, Maryland state director for the Humane Society of the United States.
"We've looked at what we consider the cruelest confinement practices," Bevan-Dangel said. "And these battery cages are one of the most inhumane tools that are still being used when we look at the farm animal landscape."
If the bill were to pass, it's estimated that six million birds would come out of cages, Bevan-Dangel said. About 11 farms that produce shell eggs in Maryland meet the criteria of 3,000 egg-laying hens, Bevan-Dangel said, but the sale prohibition would affect birds in other states as well.
According to state numbers, approximately 600 million eggs were produced in Maryland in 2022. About 10 million of those eggs came from smaller farms with fewer than 3,000 hens, which Bevan-Dangel said often use cage-free practices anyway.
But the farming community has pushed back on the legislation vigorously, citing financial concerns they say could put them out of business. Should surrounding states decide not to ban battery cages, Maryland farmers could be disadvantaged in the egg market, said Tyler Hough, director of government relations for the Maryland Farm Bureau.
"We would be forced out of business, our employees out of work," said Bill Dix of ISE America, a Maryland-based egg producer.
Some opponents argue there are cases where cage-free housing systems could even have negative effects on the welfare of hens. Access to the ground and other birds means more exposure to diseases, parasites and pecking order injuries, said veterinarian Matthew Weeman, legislative chairman for the Maryland Veterinary Medical Association.
The Maryland Veterinary Medical Association did not take a position on the bill but submitted informational testimony. Sometimes a cage is better for a bird and sometimes it isn't, said Weeman.
"We don't need a legislative mandate that says here you have to raise the bird this one way because that one way may not stand the test of time in perpetuity," Weeman said.
Many supporters of the bill argue that the egg industry is increasingly shifting toward cage-free practices anyway. By June 2023, according to the USDA, the share of cage-free hens increased to 38% of egg-laying hens in the U.S. Even large restaurant and grocery chains have made cage-free commitments, thus contributing to the increase in cage-free practices.
Weeman says this shift is not by industry choice, but instead by the work of activist groups. Some farmers are just giving in to the public pressure, he said.
Mandating cage-free eggs could price people out of buying eggs, farmers argue. In a 2023 report, the United Egg Producers determined that if regular eggs are taken from the market, the number of consumers who will forgo buying eggs will increase by 20 percentage points.
But Terrasa said this legislation would remove the cost of the premium for cage-free eggs, thus opening access to all Marylanders.
"I paid for it, that's fine," Terrasa said. "But I think everybody should be able to make that same ethical decision without the cost of the premium on it." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on legislative efforts to mandate cage-free egg production in Maryland, highlighting agricultural practices, farmer concerns about costs and animal welfare, and industry implications. While there is a governmental aspect, the core subject revolves around agricultural policies and farming methods.

title: 'Biden butchered this decision': Democrats split over U.S. lifting ban on Paraguayan beef imports
author: Mike Sunnucks APG Newspapers
content:
'Biden butchered this decision': Democrats split over U.S. lifting ban on Paraguayan beef imports

 March 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks APG Newspapers | Section: National 
 
 1037
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The six Democratic senators representing the Delmarva Peninsula voted against a measure that would reverse the Biden administration's decision to allow beef imports into the U.S. from Paraguay.The U.S. Senate voted 70-25 Thursday to reverse the administration's move to lift longstanding prohibitions on Paraguayan beef imports in an effort led by U.S. Sen. Jon Tester, D-Montana.
The agricultural and trade battle has divided Democrats and comes as U.S. beef prices could hit all-time record highs this year with production inventories at their lowest levels since the 1950s.
The White House "strongly opposes" the reversal in an issue that has split Democrats saying it will undermine U.S. trade relations including with Paraguay which has taken pro-U.S. stances related to Russia and China.
Paraguayan beef imports that been prohibited into the U.S. for the past 25 years over concerns about foot-and-mouth disease outbreaks.
The U.S. Department of Agriculture reversed that ban in November.
Tester and other critics of the change — including U.S. farm groups — worry about impacts on U.S. food supplies.
The Senate vote saw Democrats split on the issue with 26 favoring reversing the Biden decision — Majority Leader Chuck Schumer of New York along with Tester and U.S. Sens. Sherrod Brown of Ohio and Jacky Rosen of Nevada. The latter trio all face tough reelection bids in November.
Twenty-two Democrats — including Maryland's Chris Van Hollen and Ben Cardin, Delaware's Chris Coons and Tom Carper and Virginia's Mark Warner and Tim Kaine — sided with Biden's meat move.
"President Biden butchered this decision," said Tester, in a statemetn. "By cutting corners to resume beef imports from a country with a recent history of foot and mouth disease, the Biden Administration is jeopardizing our food supply and giving Montana consumers and producers a raw deal. We cannot allow beef imports from Paraguay until we have data that shows they are meeting same high animal health standards as American ranchers, and I'm proud to have secured overwhelming bipartisan support in the Senate to force the Biden administration to reverse course."
'MUST BE HALTED'
The measure still needs to pass the U.S. House.
Most Senate Republicans — including South Dakota'a Mike Rounds, Montana's Steve Daines and Minority Leader Mitch McConnell of Kentucky — vote re-impose the Paraguayan beef ban.
Rounds was the prime GOP sponsor of the measure.
U.S. agriculture and cattle industry groups — including the Livestock Marketing Association, National Farmers Union and R-CALF USA, also want Congress to nix the Biden administration's decision.
"The last time U.S. government officials stepped foot in a Paraguayan meat processing facility was in 2014. That nearly ten-year gap since the last site visit does not inspire confidence in Paraguay's animal health and food safety protocols," said Justin Tupper, president of U.S. Cattlemen's Association (USCA).
The group warns a foot-and-mouth disease outbreak (FMD) could cause as much as $99 billion in economic damages in the U.S.
Agriculture groups in Tester's home state — including the Montana Farm Bureau Federation, Montana Farmers Union and Montana Stockgrowers Association — also backed the Senate measure.
"Until it can be absolutely proven that there is no risk of an infectious animal disease outbreak in the U.S. domestic animal population caused by these imports, they must be halted," said Cyndi Johnson, president of the Montana Farm Bureau.
WHITE HOUSE PUSHES BACK
The Biden administration issued a statement to Congress March 19 opposing the Tester and Rounds-led measure.
"The administration strongly opposes passage of S.J. Res. 62, which would disapprove of the U.S. Department of Agriculture's (USDA) action to allow imports of fresh beef from Paraguay into the United States. USDA conducted a rigorous scientific evaluation including site visits, a full risk analysis, and ongoing review of the region's animal health status and concluded that the risk of fresh beef imports from Paraguay is low," the White House said.
"If enacted, S.J. Res. 62 would undermine the credibility of long-standing science-based decision-making processes respected by the U.S. and upheld in our trade agreements, and could in turn severely threaten fair access to new and existing export markets for U.S. farmers and ranchers," the White House statement to Congress continued.
The U.S. administration said the measure would indefinitely ban Paraguayan beef imports and "mark a significant setback in the United States-Paraguay bilateral relationship and U.S. credibility as a reliable economic partner across Latin America."
The White House said a pullback could have national security and geopolitical ramifications, pointing to Paraguay's condemnation of Russia's invasion of Ukraine and standing as the last South American country recognizing Taiwan.
China, in particular, has been making significant investments in Latin America and other developing regions. Russia restricted Paraguayan imports after the Ukraine rebuke.
The Biden administration was re-instituting a U.S. ban could send Paraguay into the economic arms of Moscow and/or Beijing.
"Access to the U.S. market is critical for Paraguay to recover exports lost to Russia and to withstand pressure from the PRC to withdraw diplomatic recognition of Taiwan," the White House contends.
Paraguayan beef imports would be a small slice of of the total U.S. market — 0.05% of the total market and 0.5% of imports, according to an October 2023 analysis by the USDA's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service. The USDA arm also defended its decision to ease the ban.
RECORD HIGH BEEF PRICES?
The dustup over Paraguay beef imports also comes as U.S. beef production has been dropping and prices are on the rise.
Beef and veal prices were up 7.4% in February compared to a year ago, according to the Consumer Price Index.
The American Farm Bureau Federation said beef prices could hit record highs with supplies at their lowest since 1951.
The Farm Bureau said there were 87.2 million heads of cattle in the U.S. in January. That's down the 8.9% from four years ago and the lowest inventories in 73 years.
"Farmers have been driven to sell off cattle because of severe drought conditions and the rising cost of supplies needed to support their herds. There are now fewer female cattle available for breeding, which means it will take time to restock the cattle population, AFBF said in a statement.
"The latest cattle numbers are a stark reminder of the challenges facing America's farmers and ranchers," said AFBF President Zippy Duvall. "Severe weather, high inflation and geopolitical uncertainty are taking a toll on farmers across the country, and families will see the effects in their grocery bills." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the U.S. agricultural policy regarding Paraguayan beef imports, including debates over trade, domestic production, and the impact on farmers. While economic and national policy aspects are present, the core subject is agriculture-related trade and regulatory decisions.

title: McHenrys prove resilience is key in farming
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
McHenrys prove resilience is key in farming

 March 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 627
 Words 

 Read News Document

 KENNEDYVILLE — It's a comeback story for young farmers and entrepreneurs Joe and Jenell McHenry, one that's steeped in a little bit of a miracle.That story was documented by Maryland Public Television in a segment for their show, "Maryland Farm and Harvest" where Joe and Jenell told the story of Joe's recovery after overturning a tractor, sustaining life-threatening injuries.
With help from family, friends and divine intervention, the couple said, he's back working on his business, a direct-to-consumer beef operation, McHenry's Beef in Kennedyville.
The McHenrys' segment on "Maryland Farm and Harvest," season 11 episode 12, aired on Feb. 27, part of a program featuring farm safety where viewers met Brian Freese, a rescue instructor at the National Education Center for Agriculture Safety.
Robert Ferrier, series producer of, "Maryland Farm and Harvest," for three years now, has been inspired by farmers' stories.
"They're the hardest workers I know. And they truly love what they're doing," he said.
Always on the lookout for agriculture stories, after his team met Jenell, Ferrier knew there was a great story to tell.
"The McHenrys personify the current crop of young farmers," Ferrier remarked. "They're great people."
MPT spent about three hours shooting at the McHenry property, a farm that has been in Kennedyville since 1965, with Associate Producer Luke Fisher writing the script. In a fast turnaround, the episode was created in roughly three weeks.
Further into the episode, Clendining informed the audience that farming is one of the most dangerous professions.
The McHenrys can certainly attest.
In his own words, Joe talked about how sudden his accident happened.
Nov. 5, 2022, at 6:30 a.m., Joe said they just had two weeks of terrible harvesting conditions. He was stressed, driving his tractor on US state 298, and had just glanced away to look at the dew on the soybeans.
In that flash of a moment things changed.
His wheels hit fresh gravel, and the rear end of the tractor kicked out, flipping into the ditch.
"I wasn't sure if I yanked the wheel, but that was the last thing I remembered until I woke up," Joe recounts.
He sustained a broken pelvis, dislodged spine, a puncture wound and internal bleeding.
"I was in a bad place," Joe acknowledged. Jenell can clearly remember the disconcerting events.
As emergency services rushed to the scene, she got a text from Joe's sister, asking if Joe was helping assist with the accident.
Jenell tried to contact her husband, and when she didn't receive a response, she felt something awful just happened.
Her fears were realized, when she arrived by the roadside to see the flipped tractor and her husband being loaded in the ambulance.
Joe came to before he blacked out again, with the familiar voice of a first responder, a friend's, fading. He awoke again at Christiana Care emergency room before being placed in a medicated coma to allow for healing.
Jenell prayed.
"I asked the good Lord to keep him breathing with no brain injuries, and that's what I got," she said.
With his friends and family praying, Joe underwent an experimental surgery where rods and plates were placed to help him walk again.
As MPT's narrator put it, "He would spend the next 37 days in the hospital before moving to rehab."
Joe did recover, with friends, his employees, and the community at his side.
From strong adversity, the McHenry's keep going. Something that amazes Ferrier, even after his years of working for companies like Discovery, visiting exotic locales.
More than 16 million viewers have watched "Maryland Farm and Harvest" since its debut in 2013, Ferrier said.
"We celebrate agriculture in all its forms. Whatever you raise, grow or pick, we love telling the stories."
View episodes on MPT Tuesdays at 7 p.m., or past episodes at video.mpt.tv/show/maryland-farm-harvest/. Episode segments are available on the series' YouTube channel at youtube.com/c/MarylandFarmHarvest/featured.
Check out the McHenrys' products at McHenry's Beef on Facebook or Instagram. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the McHenry family's agricultural business, their farm safety story, and resilience in farming. Key elements include their beef operation, tractor accident on a farm, and features of Maryland Farm and Harvest, directly linking to Agriculture. While Business/Economy and Local Life are tangentially relevant, Agriculture is the central theme.

title: 'Biden butchered this decision': Democrats split over U.S. lifting ban on Paraguay beef imports

'MUST BE HALTED'
The measure still needs to pass the U.S. House.
Most Senate Republicans — including South Dakota'a Mike Rounds, Montana's Steve Daines and Minority Leader Mitch McConnell of Kentucky — voted to re-impose the Paraguayan beef ban.
Rounds was the prime GOP sponsor of the measure.
U.S. agriculture and cattle industry groups — including the Livestock Marketing Association, National Farmers Union and R-CALF USA — also want Congress to nix the Biden administration's decision.
"The last time U.S. government officials stepped foot in a Paraguayan meat processing facility was in 2014. That nearly ten-year gap since the last site visit does not inspire confidence in Paraguay's animal health and food safety protocols," said Justin Tupper, president of U.S. Cattlemen's Association (USCA).
The group warns a foot-and-mouth disease outbreak (FMD) could cause as much as $99 billion in economic damages in the U.S.
Agriculture groups in Tester's home state — including the Montana Farm Bureau Federation, Montana Farmers Union and Montana Stockgrowers Association — also backed the Senate measure.
"Until it can be absolutely proven that there is no risk of an infectious animal disease outbreak in the U.S. domestic animal population caused by these imports, they must be halted," said Cyndi Johnson, president of the Montana Farm Bureau.
WHITE HOUSE PUSHES BACK
The Biden administration issued a statement to Congress March 19 opposing the Tester and Rounds-led measure.
"The administration strongly opposes passage of S.J. Res. 62, which would disapprove of the U.S. Department of Agriculture's (USDA) action to allow imports of fresh beef from Paraguay into the United States. USDA conducted a rigorous scientific evaluation including site visits, a full risk analysis, and ongoing review of the region's animal health status and concluded that the risk of fresh beef imports from Paraguay is low," the White House said.
"If enacted, S.J. Res. 62 would undermine the credibility of long-standing science-based decision-making processes respected by the U.S. and upheld in our trade agreements, and could in turn severely threaten fair access to new and existing export markets for U.S. farmers and ranchers," the White House statement to Congress continued.
The U.S. administration said the measure would indefinitely ban Paraguayan beef imports and "mark a significant setback in the United States-Paraguay bilateral relationship and U.S. credibility as a reliable economic partner across Latin America."
The White House said a pullback could have national security and geopolitical ramifications, pointing to Paraguay's condemnation of Russia's invasion of Ukraine and standing as the last South American country recognizing Taiwan.
China, in particular, has been making significant investments in Latin America and other developing regions. Russia restricted Paraguayan imports after the Ukraine rebuke.
The Biden administration warns re-instituting a U.S. ban could send Paraguay into the economic arms of Moscow and/or Beijing.
"Access to the U.S. market is critical for Paraguay to recover exports lost to Russia and to withstand pressure from the PRC to withdraw diplomatic recognition of Taiwan," the White House contends.
Paraguayan beef imports would be a small slice of the total U.S. market — 0.05% of the total market and 0.5% of imports, according to an October 2023 analysis by the USDA's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service. The USDA arm also defended its decision to ease the ban.
RECORD HIGH BEEF PRICES?
The dustup over Paraguay beef imports also comes as U.S. beef production has been dropping and prices are on the rise.
Beef and veal prices were up 7.4% in February compared to a year ago, according to the Consumer Price Index.
The American Farm Bureau Federation said beef prices could hit record highs with supplies at their lowest since 1951.
The Farm Bureau said there were 87.2 million heads of cattle in the U.S. in January. That's down the 8.9% from four years ago and the lowest inventories in 73 years.
"Farmers have been driven to sell off cattle because of severe drought conditions and the rising cost of supplies needed to support their herds. There are now fewer female cattle available for breeding, which means it will take time to restock the cattle population, AFBF said in a statement.
"The latest cattle numbers are a stark reminder of the challenges facing America's farmers and ranchers," said AFBF President Zippy Duvall. "Severe weather, high inflation and geopolitical uncertainty are taking a toll on farmers across the country, and families will see the effects in their grocery bills." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the U.S. Senate's vote regarding Paraguayan beef imports, agricultural trade policies, and their impact on domestic farmers and cattle production. Key elements include USDA decisions, farm group concerns, and economic implications for the agricultural sector, making 'Agriculture' the most precise classification.

title: Talbot County farmers markets ready for spring season
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Talbot County farmers markets ready for spring season

 April 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 667
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — As sure as bumblebees circling blossoms, the opening of Mid-Shore farmers markets is a sign of spring.The fresh and local offerings will start this weekend in St. Michaels and next weekend in Easton.
The Easton Farmers Market, opening on April 20, will be open on Saturdays from 8 a.m. to 1 p.m.
According to Marie Pierre Nuthall, the outdoor event manager for the Avalon Foundation, which runs the Easton Farmers Market, the weekly event is about supporting local artisans, bakers, farmers, watermen and more.
"Farmers markets are important because they support local small businesses," Nathall said. "The money is kept in the community. Everything you see is either grown here or produced here. Nothing is flown in. It is supporting and sustaining our own food production on the Shore."
The full scale market opening on April 20 will be an expansion of the Avalon Foundation's Winter Market, which it has run in the off-season. The full market will run until the second week of December, after which the Winter Market will pick back up.
"This year was the first that we went all year round with some vendors. This constitutes the opening of the Spring Market in its full glory as we expand to fill the entire municipal lot," Nuthall said. "We have lots of vegetables because many of our farmers are growing in high tunnels. We do have vendors there this Saturday, but the full market won't open until April 20."
The market is located in a municipal parking lot on the 100 block of North Harrison Street in downtown Easton.
Some of the vendors include Triangle Acres, Cottingham Farm, Honeybee Flower Farm, The Federal Brewing Company, CD Produce, Quarter Acre Farm and Gingersnap Farm.
The market will have several bakeries, produce growers and local honey. It will have woodworking and textile crafts for sale, along with other locally-made goods. There will be live music every Saturday starting at 10:30 a.m.
An interactive map of vendors is available at maps.managemymarket.
Nuthall said in addition to being able to view the roster of vendors for the duration of the calendar year, those who visit the link can also view vendor contact information, the types of items they sell and their location in the market.
There is parking available at Brewer's Lane, or the lot on the corner of Washington and Bay Streets. There will be a marked accessible parking space for those with disability parking needs.
The St. Michaels Farmers Market will be open from April 13 to Nov. 23 on Saturdays from 8:30 to 11:30 a.m. It is located on 206 S. Talbot Street.
"(St. Michaels Farmers Market) is in its 27th season and is the small town, producer-only farmers market of Maryland's Eastern Shore," said Market Manager Sandy Lawler. "We are also the only market on the Eastern Shore that has a SNAP dollar for dollar matching program."
Like Easton, the St. Michaels market has a wide array of bakers, farmers and artisans. Some of these include Little Fields Floral, Tilghman Island Baking, D&D Dog Treats, Scottish Highland Creamery, Chesapeake Mushrooms and Lyon Rum. There is also a weekly changing community and education tent and weekly musicians. Building African American Minds will be in the community and education tent on opening day.
For veggies, vendors include Shaky Wheelbarrow Herb Sales, Krieder's Tomatoes, Oksana's Produce Farm, Vintage Family Farm and Mindful Acres. Cottingham will have organic vegetables.
Night Kitchen Coffee Roasters, Casa Carmen Wines, Willwaw Farm, Fat and Happy Farms and Agave Juice and Elysium Farm will all be offering their creations.
Lawler put her finger on why this market is so enduring.
"Farmers Markets are important for so many reasons," she said. "... The biggest one is the support of our own community. Neighbor feeding neighbor with minimal transport, which means fresher healthier products including a lower environmental impact. Knowing your farmer means you are buying from someone who is a steward of the land."
Opening day, the market will have Talbot County Public Schools students playing from 8:30 to 9:30 a.m., followed by WabiSabi to close.
For more information, call 410-713-0507. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on farmers markets as a platform for local agricultural producers, emphasizing support for small farms, local food systems, and community economic activity. While Business/Economy is relevant, the core subject is agriculture-related due to the direct connection to farming, produce, and rural economic practices.

title: Strawberry season has arrived
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Strawberry season has arrived

 April 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1299
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Strawberries are arriving in stores, just-opening produce stands and at the fields on the farm.My mother grew several fields of strawberries, and we all picked them along with hired local pickers. Many places feature pick-your-own berries, and what fun this can be with your family.
Watch this paper and other local media sources for the popular Strawberry Festival. I remember all those wooden strawberry crates filled with berries, loaded on the flatbed trailers being pulled by the tractor and taken to town and the auction block.
There were many other farmers there with berries as well. At the end of the day, each picker would be given tickets to indicate the number of quarts they picked and on the last day of working that week the tickets were redeemed for cash.
A lot of men, women and children made money that way to pay their bills, buy food and survive. Mom would always save lots of berries for our family to make preserves, cakes, pies, cobblers and delicious strawberry ice cream.
STRAWBERRY CHICKEN SALAD
In a medium bowl place 2 cups fresh baby greens, 1 cup washed and sliced fresh strawberries, 1/2 to 3/4 cup mandarin oranges, 6-ounce precooked chicken breast (chilled and sliced), one tablespoon sliced toasted almonds, 1/2 to 3/4 ounce sliced red onions, and 4 ounces poppy seed dressing. Toss and serve. This will serve two, so double this for serving more.
STRAWBERRY COFFEE CAKE MUFFINS
¼ cup unsalted butter (softened), ½ cup granulated sugar, 1 egg, 1 teaspoon vanilla extract, 2 teaspoons baking powder, pinch of salt, ½ cup buttermilk, 1½ cups all-purpose flour, 2 cups fresh strawberries (diced small). For the crumble: ½ cup all-purpose flour, ¼ cup butter (chilled and cubed), ¼ cup brown sugar, ¼ cup granulated sugar.
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Line a 12-cup standard muffin tin with paper liners or coat with nonstick spray. Set aside. To make crumble: In a medium bowl, combine granulated sugar, brown sugar, flour and chilled cubed butter. Stir with a fork or pastry blender until the mixture is crumbly. Set in the fridge until ready to use. To make muffins: In a large mixing bowl cream the butter and granulated sugar until light and fluffy. Add egg, vanilla extract and buttermilk, beat until well combined. Sift in the flour, baking powder and pinch of salt, and beat on low speed until just mixed. Gently fold in about half of the strawberries. Fill muffin liners ¾ full with batter, top with remaining strawberries and then sprinkle crumble on the tops of the muffins. Bake for 18-20 minutes, until the muffins are lightly browned on top and a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean
STRAWBERRY PIE
Make and bake one 9-inch pie shell, let cool and set aside. Wash and cap a large carton of fresh strawberries and let dry. When the berries are dry, place small and medium sized berries in the pie shell. Start in the middle of the shell and work out to the edges, trying to fill the shell without leaving spaces. I slice berries to have a full shell. Any berries left over, place in a heavy saucepan where we will make the filling. In this heavy saucepan, combine 1 cup sugar, 1/8 teaspoon salt, 3 heaping tablespoons of cornstarch with the leftover berries. Mash well with potato masher getting juices out — let juices stay in the mixture. Heat and stir at the same time until mixture begins to thicken. Take off the stove and stir in one teaspoon lemon juice. Stir and cool — pour over berries in a pie shell and spread evenly with a spoon. Top with whipped cream.
STRAWBERRY COBBLER
Beat 1 egg and 1/2 cup milk together and add 2 cups flour, 3 teaspoons baking powder, 3/4 teaspoon salt, 2 tablespoons sugar and 5 tablespoons shortening. Mix well and spread in a 9x13x2 inch pan and cover the bottom of the pan and sides of the pan. Pour two quarts washed, capped whole strawberries on top of the dough — if berries are too large then slice in half. Then beat 2 eggs, 1/2 cup milk, and 1 teaspoon vanilla and pour on top of berries. Add 1 1/2 cups sugar on top of the mixture. Sprinkle with cinnamon. Bake at 375 degrees for 45 minutes or until done.
STRAWBERRY RHUBARB PIE
1 cup + 2 tablespoons granulated sugar, 6 tablespoons cornstarch, 1/2 teaspoon salt, 1 pound fresh rhubarb, 1 pund strawberries (stemmed and quartered), 1 tablespoon orange juice, 2 teaspoons orange zest, 2 teaspoons vanilla bean paste or vanilla extract, 1 large egg, 2 tablespoons turbinado sugar.
Preheat the oven to 375 degrees. Place a foil-lined rimmed baking sheet on the center rack of the oven to preheat. Roll out 1 piece of dough on a floured surface into a 12-inch round, starting at the center and working your way out. (Sprinkle flour over the top of the dough if it's a bit too moist.) Carefully lift the dough and place in a 9-inch pie pan (not deep dish); gently press against the sides of the pan. Trim excess overhanging dough at the edge of the pie plate. Stir together the sugar, cornstarch, and salt in a large bowl until evenly combined. Add the rhubarb, strawberries, orange juice, orange zest, and vanilla. Toss until evenly coated. Pour the fruit mixture into the pie crust. Roll out the other piece of dough into a 12-inch round on a floured surface. Cut into eight 1 1/2-inch-wide strips. Arrange 4 strips of dough in parallel rows on top of the filling. Working with one strip at a time, arrange the remaining 4 strips perpendicular to the first ones, weaving the strips over and under to form a lattice. Trim the ends of the strips and press them against the bottom crust. Press with a fork all around the edge of the pie crust to crimp.
In a small bowl, whisk the egg and 1 tablespoon of water with a fork. Brush the dough lightly with the egg wash and sprinkle with the turbinado sugar. Bake the pie until the filling is bubbly and thickened in the middle of the pie, 1 hour 20 minutes to 1 hour 30 minutes. (Cover the pie with foil if the crust is getting too dark after 45 minutes.) Allow the pie to cool to room temperature before slicing, about 4 hours.
STRAWBERRY BREAD
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Grease and flour two 9-inch loaf pans, set aside. Wash and cap and slice 2 quarts of fresh berries. Drain well and place in a medium bowl. Stir in 4 beaten eggs, 3 cups all purpose flour, 2 cups sugar, sugar, 3 teaspoons cinnamon, 1 teaspoon salt, 1 teaspoon baking soda, 1 1/4 cups cooking oil, and 1 cup chopped nuts. Mix well and pour into prepared pans and bake one hour or until a toothpick inserted comes out clean.
STRAWBERRY LEMONADE
1 pound strawberries (plus more to garnish), 1 1/2 cups granulated sugar, 2 cups fresh lemon juice (strained and divided), ice, lemon slices to garnish. Hull and quarter the strawberries. Place the strawberries in a large bowl, stir in the sugar and ¼ cup lemon juice. Allow to sit, covered for 30 minutes. In a countertop blender, blend the strawberry mixture until pureed. Strain the mixture through a fine mesh sieve to get the seeds out. In a large bowl, combine the strawberry puree with the remaining 1 ¾ cups of lemon juice and 4 cups of water. Add up to 1 additional cup of water to taste if the mixture is too sweet or strong. To serve, stir the lemonade and pour it over ice. Garnish with sliced lemon and strawberries.
Enjoy picking berries with family and friends. I will include more berry recipes before the season is over and we get closer to summer. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on strawberry farming, harvest practices, and local agricultural traditions, including pick-your-own operations and family-based farming. While it includes recipes, the core theme revolves around agricultural production and rural livelihoods rather than food culture or local events alone.

title: Farm fresh: State visit highlights local agriculture
author: Staff Writer
content:
Farm fresh: State visit highlights local agriculture

 May 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Business 
 
 186
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Maryland Agriculture Secretary Kevin Atticks recently embarked on a tour of Queen Anne's County, where he visited several farms showcasing excellence in local farming programs. These farms highlighted innovative initiatives supported by both local and state grant funding operations, furthering their commitment to sustainable agriculture and environmental stewardship.The tour began at Kristy's Backyard Blooms, a family-run business situated outside Centreville. Kristy Dulin showcased her farm's greenhouse, which received funding support through a state grant. In addition to poultry and grain production, Kristy's Backyard Blooms has successfully integrated a flower business into their business footprint
The tour also include Oksana's Produce Farm in Chestertown, where Secretary Atticks met with Oksana Bocharova, the farm's owner. Bocharova passion for farming was nurtured by her father in Russia. Oksana's Produce Farm employs sustainable farming methods and organic practices.
County Commissioner Jack Wilson expressed pride in showcasing local farms that exemplify Maryland's agricultural heritage and commitment to sustainability.
For more information on the Maryland Department of Agriculture and its initiatives, please visit https://mda.maryland.gov/Pages/default.aspx
For more information about Kristy's Backyard Blooms, follow her on social media @KristysBackyardBlooms
For more information about Oksana's Produce Farm, visit https://oksanasproduce.com/

title: Farmers’ Market ‘ramps’ up for spring season
author: LISA J. GOTTO Special to the Kent County News
content:
Farmers’ Market ‘ramps’ up for spring season

 May 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LISA J. GOTTO Special to the Kent County News | Section: Entertainment 
 
 1135
 Words 

 Read News Document

 High Street between Queen Street and Spring Avenue along Chestertown's main thoroughfare is humming again on Saturdays with shoppers, strollers, and the sights and sounds of a crowd in the midst of an essential weekly ritual centered around sustenance.Open weekly from 8 a.m. to noon, that sustenance is just as much about the mind and spirit, as it is about the body. However, market goers—local residents and out-of-towners alike—seem to revel in an esprit de corp that happens when an established and enriched agricultural and artisan community bands together to feed the stomach—and the soul.
The farmers market is year-around put picks up more vendors and bigger crowds when the weather warms.
Most, if not all, of the long list of vendors were back in full force now that the spring and summer version of the Chestertown Farmers' Market is back in town and from the sounds of vendors and participants alike, it is going to be another robust season of fresh fruits, hardy veggies, and all manner of creative arts and handmade crafts.
Two of those creative vendors, Tolchester resident Mary Faulkner of Falling Branch Jewelry, Oil Paintings, and Sculpture, and Beverly Miller of Beve's Creations enjoyed the warm sunshine and chatted with various 9 a.m.-hour market goers.
"I really like talking to the people who purchase what I do, the paintings and the jewelry," said Faulkner. "It's a really nice community and this is a nice way to sell my work."
Miller, who sells colorful handmade quilts from her vendor stand, said she also enjoys the sense of conviviality created at the market and the level of talent that can be found there, as she touted the technique that Faulkner used to create a mural on a wall in her home in Worton. Instances of camaraderie are common occurrences at the market, they said.
A bit further down the artisans row, Mary Yirka of Chestertown and her dog, Eddie, displayed some beautiful and unique jewelry pieces and small-batch greeting cards for sale.
"Everyone is so friendly to Mr. Ed," Yirka said of her furry, neck-tied buddy who often attends the market with her.
Yirka described the art for sale at the market as diverse and one-of-a-kind.
"You see something different every weekend and you never get bored."
With just two weeks to go until one of the biggest event weekends in town, the Chestertown Tea Party Festival volunteer committee booth fielded questions of all sorts, ahead of the 250th anniversary of the festival which is set to take place starting on May 24 and running through the 26th.
"I was unaware that this was the 250th anniversary year of the festival. I'm so glad you're here like this," said a new market shopper, Yolanda Stuart of Rock Hall, of the committee volunteers tending the booth. Along with answering questions about parking, bringing pets, and what foods we might anticipate enjoying, the committee members were on hand at the market to create the buzz that will no doubt bring the visitors from far and wide.
"This Tea Party is actually larger than Boston's," said Committee Member-at-Large, Nina Fleegle, of the event, which she added was attended by 30,000 people last year.
Being a conduit of communication and a support system for the underlying greater community has become a function of the market, which has been a fixture on High Street since it was formally established in 1981. What started out as an outlet for organic produce has grown to attract vendors from across Maryland and beyond offering many different types of products.
"Chestertown has become one of our staples on the Eastern Shore," said Kari Parreco, who was tending the Gray Wolf Spirits stand.
"The people are so nice here and they tend to appreciate when something is handcrafted," she said of the spirits produced by their St. Michaels-based distillery.
In addition to spirits, fine local wine, chocolates, fresh pasta, fresh-cut flowers, pet treats, meats, dairy products, (even duck eggs) and artisanal breads from the market's newest vendor, Lucky Heart Bakery, are all available for purchase—and people are coming from all over to shop here.
"It's not uncommon, especially during this season to hear people say 'I'm here from Lancaster for the weekend', or 'I've come from Annapolis, D.C. or Pasadena'," said Zach LeDoux of Happy Chicken Bakery and Catering.
LeDoux, who co-owns the business with his wife, Martha, credited the market with helping grow their business from an enterprise that gleaned $100 per outing when they started out five years ago, to one that he says has grown "exponentially."
Like LeDoux, Melissa McGlynn of McGlynn's Cottage Pies said her business simply would not exist without the market, which turned out to be a godsend during COVID when her role as pastry chef at a local restaurant was cut and she needed to pivot.
"I just started thinking about what else I could do, and what the town wasn't already doing, and I thought pies, hearty, savory pies."
Those hearty, savory pies are now market favorites, and are great for those who struggle with their schedules and meal-planning.
And when it comes to meals, Chestertown Farmers' Market Manager, Julia Medrano, said she feels the market and its substantial offerings can be the place where you can easily shop for a week's worth of meals that are both healthy and sustaining.
Medrano, who has been in her role since 2019, sees the market as a huge foundation for the community and its people.
The market, she said, has several things going for it: excellent word-of-mouth advertising, a beautiful location, and the bounty that comes from acres upon acres of local farms.
"Kent County is such an agricultural county and the Farmers' Market really caters to that. It really shows the public that this is where you can get your meals," Medrano said.
The market, she added, is also the place where people come to see people they know, so the socialization factor is huge.
And the vendors are also your neighbors or someone you know, she explained, which is a great way to put money right back into the community; all contributing to what she sees as a bright future for the market.
"We moved to a non-profit, so we have a board now, and I'm looking forward to their ideas and their implementation … I hope it just continues to grow."
All tasty baked goods, bouquets, and boutique bourbon aside, it's clear that taking time to stroll High Street on Market Saturday reaps benefits beyond finding the perfect melon.
In fact, Saturday mornings at the market has become such an experience, that attendee Julie Armstrong, said her mother, Mary, requested it as her primary Mother's Day activity with her daughter. A graduate of Washington College, Armstrong, who now resides in Reisterstown, described her trip back to Chestertown's Market as 'nostalgic'.
"It's very poignant to be back," Armstrong said. "This place has so much gravity to it; it's hard to stay away for too long." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the Chestertown Farmers' Market, highlighting its role in agriculture through local vendors, seasonal produce, and community engagement. While it touches on arts/culture (artisans, crafts) and business/economy (vendor growth, local commerce), the central theme is agricultural activity and its community impact.

title: Farm Bill faces cuts to critical food programs
author: ALBERT R. WYNN
content:
Farm Bill faces cuts to critical food programs

 May 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ALBERT R. WYNN | Section: Columns 
 
 834
 Words 

 Read News Document

 After recently voting to keep the government funded, Congress is expected to turn to a laundry list of pressing legislative items. Among these are tackling the fiscal year 2025 appropriations bills and reauthorizing the Farm Bill, which is set to expire at the end of the fiscal year. The Farm Bill is an incredibly important law that invests in our farmers to keep rural communities growing, helps export more American agriculture products abroad and ensures food security for tens of millions of lower-income families.In the words of former President Obama, the Farm Bill is a "Swiss army knife" for the country, and it's time for Congress to put pen to paper and deliver.
The Farm Bill is normally an incredibly bipartisan endeavor and often passes with broad bipartisan support. This time, things are likely to be a bit different as some leading Republicans, including a Maryland congressman, are seeking to poison legislative progress by seeking spending cuts to critical programs and product restrictions that would leave millions of our neighbors worse off.
As the party of choice, dignity, and compassion, Democrats should continue to stand up to the other sides efforts to disrupt the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) and funding for Women, Infants and Children (WIC). This is a dual-track threat: calling for pilot programs to "test" restriction in the appropriations process and potential amendments to enact restrictions in the Farm Bill.
This issue is as real as ever. In recent weeks, some Republicans have stood as a roadblock to expanding funding to WIC as leverage to score a pilot program on product restrictions within SNAP.
In my view, extreme Republicans are wrong to play politics with anti-hunger funding for mothers and their children. These are real people, and politicians should put them in the crossfire in order to win a personal policy priority. As the National WIC Association said recently, these efforts are "unnecessary and harmful," and undermines the "success of a program that has enjoyed decades of overwhelming bipartisan support."
Essentially, the unrealistic demand is for a five-state pilot program to restrict retailers from accepting SNAP benefits for items that are not "nutrient-dense" foods. Their stated goal is to eliminate the ability for lower-income consumers to buy snacks, candy, and sodas and it also opens the question as to what it means to be "nutrient-dense" and how this program will be enforced in the real world. It could also add new burdens and headaches onto America's 248,000 retailers, the overwhelming majority of which are small businesses, if this pilot were to go nationwide.
Thankfully, when Republicans were attempting to stuff this bad idea into one of the most recent funding bills, Democrats held strong and stopped its inclusion. As Democratic leadership noted, this policy is "extreme" and the Republican proposal "would have limited food choices for people on SNAP."
Not only are these Republicans on the wrong side politically, but the policy position is also extreme. In addition to pushing a pilot program, there is also a misguided proposal floating around with an oft-named Healthy SNAP Act, a bill that would restrict consumer choice in the grocery store. Specifically, the proposal would prohibit recipients from purchasing certain food items such as soft beverages and snacks.
While this legislation seeks to lower obesity rates, it fails to consider that Americans get their food from more than one aisle of the grocery store.
The truth is choices lead to better outcomes, and the private sector is on the front lines of lowering caloric intake in their products. Take a walk through the soft drink or snack aisle — consumers today have more options than ever, with diet, zero calorie and reduced sugar options. Consumers should be empowered to make the best decisions for themselves and their families when they are purchasing products they enjoy. Republicans claim to believe in limited government, but in this case, they want to have the government limit consumer choice.
The proposal also infringes on the dignity of SNAP recipients, many of whom are people of color. Recipients of SNAP know the importance of a balanced diet, and they don't need the government to make those decisions for them.
We all recognize that obesity in America is a real problem, but the solution for this complex issue won't be found by banning soda, snacks and other products from the SNAP program. As the former CEO of Johns Hopkins All Children's Hospital, noted in a recent piece, "There's little reason to believe that the use of SNAP funds to purchase sodas would do much to reduce obesity at the population level. The Food and Drug Administration reports that, as of 2020, less than 6% of the typical diet is made up of sugar-sweetened beverages."
As negotiations on the Farm Bill progress, let's hope the Healthy SNAP Act and corresponding pilot programs are added to the shredder and not to the actual bill. Consumers and businesses would be better off with keeping the status quo.
Albert R. Wynn is a former member of the U.S. House of Representatives, representing Maryland's 4th Congressional District. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the Farm Bill, which is a core agricultural policy legislation. It discusses agricultural programs like SNAP and WIC, congressional debates over farm subsidies, and impacts on rural communities and food security. While there are economic and health-related elements, the central theme is agricultural policy and its legislative framework.

title: Community shows up for local farmer
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Community shows up for local farmer

 May 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 437
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Wayne Cawley, owner of Redemption Farms, said he owns a "faith-based" produce farm. That was not more apparent to Cawley than during this strawberry season, when hundreds of community members gathered in the rain to show the local farmer some support.Cawley said they had a perfect storm for a terrible season for their crop.
In a short window, his farm had a concentrated harvest of strawberries due to a condensed winter when too much fruit appeared all at once. Not enough people were picking strawberries at their "U-Pick" hours, so much of the strawberry crop was not generating profit.
On top of all that, there was a lot of rain. Cawley describes rain as "kryptonite" for strawberries.
In an attempt to generate more business, Cawley posted a video on social media asking for help and offering a buy one, get one free sale on the "U-Pick" strawberries. The next morning, people were waiting in the parking lot.
"We had strawberries everywhere that were red and ripe and needed to be picked, and it looked like we were going to lose all those strawberries to rain," Cawley said. "We just reached out and asked for help telling people about the situation, and it was absolutely amazing how many people came out."
Cawley said the community showed up for him in the rain by the hundreds. Under large umbrellas and bright raincoats, people showed up with their families to help pick over an acre and a half of strawberries.
Nancy Minahan, owner of Caroline's, a restaurant near the farm, said she and her husband went out during the weekend to help Cawley's farm. Minahan said she was astonished by the amount of people who appeared to help. She was happy to see people showing up for local farmers.
"We just all need to support our local farmers as much as we can," Minahan said. "People need to understand how hard they work and occasionally need help. We can't control the weather; we can't control a lot of things. And if there's anything we can do to help them, that's great."
Cawley said it was humbling to see the community step up and support his farm. He believes it is essential for small businesses to have faith and ask for help from the community when needed.
"Don't be afraid to step out in faith," Cawley said. "It sounds corny, but honestly, when you let go, let God take care of it. It's amazing where you can go and what you can do and really how silly you are for worrying about things because you can't control anything. We can't control the weather. We can't control anything." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a local farmer's agricultural challenges and community support for his produce farm, directly relating to Agriculture. While Local Life and Business/Economy are nearby themes, the core subject is the agricultural operation and its community engagement.

title: Appellate court upholds right-to-farm protection for Trappe farm
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Appellate court upholds right-to-farm protection for Trappe farm

 June 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 646
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Last week, the Appellate Court of Maryland upheld a right-to-farm protection for Trappe's Foster Farm.The decision overruled a Talbot County Circuit Court decision and affirmed the original stance on the use of a soil conditioner taken by the Talbot County Agricultural Resolution Board in December 2022.
The Delmarva Chicken Association, along with the Maryland Farm Bureau and Maryland Grain Producers Association, applauded the decision.
"As Maryland's rural regions face increasing pressure from development, it's crucial to protect farmers' (rights) and to keep commonly accepted agricultural practices in their toolboxes," DCA Executive Director Holly Porter said in a press release. "Even though this lawsuit did not directly involve a chicken grower, a loss in court would have been detrimental to every farmer and grower in the state."
Original complaints were filed to the board in September 2021 by a number of neighbors and residents, many of whom claimed the farm emanated odors from a stockpiling of sludge-like materials sent to the farm by Denali Water Solutions.
The board heard resident and expert testimonies, and determined the Denali soil conditioner that included processed clams was responsible for the odor. Residents described feeling nauseous and dizzy, while others said their children could not play outside with the odor and its effects.
"There is no dispute that the strong smells coming from the farm were caused by the Denali soil conditioners that were both stockpiled and applied to the soil on the Foster farm," the Board wrote in 2022.
Denali and the Foster Farm agreed to cease stockpiling and usage of the product that contained the processed clams at that location.
The circuit court reversed the original decision after determining the time between the placement of the soil conditioners and the submission of complaints was less than the one year that state and county code protects.
"The storage of industrial waste was never there before and should not have been protected by the right-to-farm act," said Cheryl Lewis, one of the appellees.
While appellees argued that the farm's operations changed so much as to reset the one-year protection period, the appellate court said state code is ambiguous as to whether that period resets "when an agricultural operation changes its methodology/approach."
"Based on the legislative history, non-negligent agricultural operations — those that are compliant with the necessary regulations and that have been under way for one year or more — are shielded from nuisance claims when expanding a nutrient management program," the appellate court's ruling read.
County code "demonstrates that agricultural land may change the modality of its operations without losing liability protection," Judge Glenn T. Harrell Jr. wrote.
Choptank Riverkeeper Matt Pluta, who spoke at the original Board hearing in 2022, said the product was especially concerning in terms of pollution.
"They've got this huge pond on site right there that drains the local waterway," Pluta said. "The stockpiling of the clam bellies occurred right next to the pond. It wasn't well contained. It was seen running off the storage site after rain events."
Attorney Mark Cropper, who represents both Denali and farm operator Arthur Foster Jr., declined comment for this story.
The regulation of similar industrial waste and dissolved air flotation (DAF) residuals — a sludge-like material stemming from food plants that process wastewater — has been a hot button topic at both the county and state levels.
According to previous Star Democrat reporting, Caroline County Commissioners adopted four resolutions earlier this year to place moratoriums on the storage of DAF residuals, with the hope to buy more time for the county to consider regulations.
Last month, Gov. Wes Moore signed a bill requiring anyone who wishes to use or store food processing residuals to obtain a permit from the Department of Agriculture.
"I think it brought to light a lot of the inadequacies we have here in Maryland for using this material," Pluta said of the Foster Farm case. "I think we're going to see a different path forward with this new legislation." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a legal decision regarding agricultural practices, specifically the right-to-farm protection for a farm using soil conditioners. It involves agricultural regulations, disputes between farmers and residents, and implications for farming operations. While environmental concerns and local government regulations are mentioned, the core subject is agriculture.

title: Queen Anne's Ag Awareness Day lauds essay winners
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Queen Anne's Ag Awareness Day lauds essay winners

 June 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 412
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Students learning the value of local agriculture were recognized for their essays during the Queen Anne's County Public School Board of Education meeting June 5 as the Agricultural Awareness Committee recently hosted its annual Agriculture Awareness Day and essay contest.Seventh grade students were invited to participate in hands-on educational experiences to learn about Maryland's crucial homegrown farming industry as the Agricultural Awareness Committee hosted its seventh annual Agriculture Awareness Day April 9 and 10 at the Queen Anne's County 4-H Park, in Centreville, according to Michael Page, curriculum supervisor.
Understanding where food comes from is a fundamental aspect of the world and a coalition of agricultural educators and professionals joined together to host an invaluable educational experience for all seventh grade students across the county, Page said. The days were filled with numerous agriculture topics and allowed the students to have many hands-on experiences at learning stations lead by industry experts including aquaculture, grain, farm animals, food safety and pollination, he said,
This year in particular focused on the variety of career opportunities available within local agriculture, according to Page.
"Even if it's in ag, you might not be a farmer," said Jenell Eck McHenry of Thompson Ag Consulting Programs.
"Our whole premise of the day is to start to get students to really realize what is agriculture, how does it affect their lives, and so on," he said.
After the two-day event, seventh-grade students penned essays to showcase what they discovered and answer the question, "How did your experience change the way you view agriculture?"
The Agricultural Awareness Committee reviewed the essays and selected the most impactful responses as winners.
The overall winner of the essay contest was Ellamae Athey of Centreville Middle School.
For Centreville Middle School, first place was awarded to Sara Klakring, second place was a tie between Teyauna Johnson and Wyatt Stephens and third place was a tie between Lucas Henderson and JP Tyler.
For Matapeake Middle School, first place was awarded to Delaney Grace Pugh, second place to Vivian Dorsey and third place to Jessica Lynn Busch.
For Stevensville Middle School, first place was presented to Conner Paterno.
Constantly growing, this year's event saw over 100 volunteers dedicating their time and resources including animals to showcase ag awareness to the community seventh graders, said Lee Bridgman University of Maryland Extension Program Assistant Agriculture and Horticulture.
The partnership between the Queen Anne's County schools and the agricultural community continues to make an educating and exciting program and is already looking forward to next year, Page said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on an agricultural awareness event for students, highlighting local agriculture, hands-on learning about farming, aquaculture, and career opportunities in the agricultural sector. While education is a component, the primary subject is agriculture.

title: Around 28,000 chickens killed in Federalsburg fire
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Around 28,000 chickens killed in Federalsburg fire

 June 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 233
 Words 

 Read News Document

 FEDERALSBURG — A chicken house fire in Federalsburg killed approximately 28,000 chickens Sunday morning.According to a release from the State Fire Marshal's office, the fire occurred just before 5:30 a.m. Sunday in a building owned by Possum Hill Farms on Possum Hill Road. No injuries were reported.
Federalsburg Volunteer Fire Company Chief Steve Cox said the fire was in the center of the building. Crews of firefighters worked from both ends to stop the blaze.
The State Fire Marshal's office said the fire took about an hour-and-a-half to control. It listed the cause as an electrical failure in the pump room. Cox said the damage was significant.
"None of that's saveable, they've got to destroy all that," Cox said. "They'll probably tear the chicken house down. So there's really not a save for anybody. We stopped it from going any further, but they can't save anything."
He added that other fire companies were a "big help" in containing the fire, including crews from Denton, Preston and Greenwood, Delaware.
"If I didn't have them, we'd have a worse situation," Cox said.
While the loss of chickens was extreme, State Fire Marshal Deputy Chief Caryn McMahon said the departments were able to prevent the fire from spreading and destroying the barns.
"The fire department controlled it pretty well," McMahon said. "Typically the poultry barns, once they ignite, it spreads pretty quickly because of the dust and materials inside of the barn."
